fields: Define electric charge. Give SI unit. Is it scalar or vector?
Electric charge is an intrinsic property of elementary particles of matter which gives rise to electric force between various objects. It is a scalar quantity, and it's SI unit is Coloumb (\(C\))
What do we mean by quantization of charge?

Charge is always in the form of an integral multiple of electronic charge and never its fraction. \[q=\pm n e\] where
\(n\) = integer
\(e\) = \(1.6 \times 10^{-19} C\)
What do we mean by conservation of charge?

• Net charge of an isolated physical system always remains constant.
  • Charge can neither be created nor destroyed; it can be transferred from one body to another.
What do we mean by additivity of charge?
Electric charge is additive, that is, the total charge is the algebraic sum of the individual charges.
State Coulomb's inverse square law.

Coulomb's inverse square law states that the electrostatic force of attraction or repulsion acting between two stationary point charges is given by
\[F=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}} {r^{2}}\] where
\(F\) = force between two charges \(q_{1}\) and \(q_{2}\) separated by a distance \(r\) in free space
\(\varepsilon_{0}\) = permittivity of free space
Value of \(\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\) \(=\) \(9 \times 10^{9} \quad N \space m^2 \space C^{-2}\)
What is the value and unit of \(\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\)?
\(\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\) \(=\) \(9 \times 10^{9} \quad N \space m^2 \space C^{-2}\)
What is dielectric constant / relative permittivity?

If free space is replaced by a medium in Coloumb's inverse square law, then \(\varepsilon = \varepsilon_{0} K = \varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{r}\), where \(K\) is known as dielectric constant or relative permittivity. \[\begin{aligned} F =\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon} \cdot \cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{r^{2}} &=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} K} \cdot \cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{r^{2}} \\ &=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{r}} \cdot \cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{r^{2}} \end{aligned}\]

  • \(K=\cfrac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{0}}\) or \(\varepsilon_{r}=\cfrac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_{0}}\)
  • \(K=1\) for vacuum (or air)
    \(K=\infty\) for conductor/metal.
  • \(\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \quad \space C ^{2} \space N ^{-1} \space m ^{-2}\)
Give the formula for the vector form of Coloumb's Law.

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{F}_{12} &=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{\left|\vec{r}_{1}-\vec{r}_{2}\right|^{3}} \space \left(\vec{r}_{1}-\vec{r}_{2}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q_{1} q_{2}}{r_{21}^{3}} \space \vec{r}_{21} \end{aligned}\]
Give the formula for linear charge distribution.

\[\lambda=\cfrac{dq}{dl}\] where
\(\lambda=\) linear charge density
Give the formula for surface charge distribution.

\[\sigma=\cfrac{dq}{dS}\] where
\(\sigma=\) surface charge density
Give the formula for volume charge distribution.

\[\rho=\cfrac{dq}{dV}\] where
\(\rho=\) volume charge density
What is electric field intensity? Give it's formula.

The electric field intensity at any point due to source charge is defined as the force experienced per unit positive test charge placed at that point without disturbing the source charge.
\[\vec{E}=\lim _{q_{0} \rightarrow 0} \cfrac{\vec{F}}{q_{0}}\]
Here, \(q_{0} \rightarrow 0\), i.e., the test charge \(q_{0}\) must be small, so that it does not produce its own electric field.
SI unit of electric field intensity (\(E\)) is \(N C^{-1}\) and it is a vector quantity, and \(E \propto \cfrac{1}{r^{2}}\)
Electric charge is a {{c1::scalar}} quantity. (scalar/vector?)
SI unit of electric charge is {{c1::Coloumb (\(C\))}}.
{{c1::Millikan's oil drop}} experiment showed the discrete nature of charge. (Charge cannot be fractional multiple of \(e\). )
Electric charge is {{c1::invariant}} as it does not depend upon the motion of the charged body or the observer.
Value of \(\varepsilon_{0}\) \(=\) {{c1::\(8.85 \times 10^{-12} \quad \space C ^{2} \space N ^{-1} \space m ^{-2}\)}}
Dimensional formula of \(\varepsilon_{0}\) is {{c1::\(\left[ M ^{-1} \space L ^{-3} \space T ^{4} \space A ^{2}\right]\)}}.
The SI unit of electric field intensity (\(E\)) is {{c1::\(N C^{-1}\)}}.
Give the formula for electric field intensity due to a point charge.
\[\vec{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{q}{|r|^{2}} \hat{r}\]
Give the formula for determining electric field due to a system of charges.
\[\begin{array}{l} \vec{E}&=\vec{E}_{1}+\vec{E}_{2}+\vec{E}_{3}+\ldots \ldots \ldots+\vec{E}_{n} \\ &=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \cfrac{q_{i}}{|r|^{2}} \hat{r}_{i} \end{array}\]
What is an electric dipole?

Two equal and opposite charges \((q)\) each, separated by a small distance \((2 l)\) constitute an electric dipole. Many of the atoms/molecules are dipoles.
\[\vec{p}=2 q \vec{l}\]

  • Dipole moment is a vector quantity and is directed from negative to positive charge.
  • SI unit of dipole moment is \(C \space m\).
  • Dimension of dipole moment = \([ATL]\)
Give the formula for determining intensity of electric field due to a dipole. along the axis.

\[\vec{E}=\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{2 \vec{p}}{r^{3}}\]

  • Direction of \(E\) is along the direction of dipole moment.
Give the formula for determining intensity of electric field due to a dipole. along the equator.

\[\vec{E}=\frac{-1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\vec{p}}{r^{3}}\]

  • Direction of \(E\) is antiparallel to direction of \(p\).
What is the electric force on a dipole inside a uniform electric field?
The resultant electric force on dipole \(=q E-q E=0\)
What is the torque experienced by a dipole inside a uniform electric field?

Two forces \(q E\) and \((-q E)\) equal and opposite, separated by a distance constitute แบก couple (Torque). \[\begin{aligned} \tau &=\vec{p} \times \vec{E} \\ &=p E \sin \theta \end{aligned}\]

  • The direction of \(\tau\) is perpendicular to the plane containing \(\vec{p}\) and \(\vec{E}\).
  • The torque tends to align the dipole in the direction of field.
Draw a graph showing the variation of \(\vec{E}\) versus \(\vec{\tau}\), for an electric dipole inside a uniform electric field.
When is the torque maximum and minimum on a dipole inside a uniform electric field?

• Torque is maximum when \(\theta=90^{\circ}\) i.e., dipole is perpendicular to \(E\).
    \(\therefore\) Maximum torque \(=p E\).
  • When \(\theta=0^{\circ}\) or \(180^{\circ}\) then \(\tau_{\min }=0\).
State Gauss's Law.
For a closed surface enclosing a net charge \(q\), the net electric flux \(\phi\) emerging out is given by \[\phi=\oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{S}=\cfrac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}}\]
Draw a diagram representing electric field due to a single positive or negative charge.
Draw a diagram representing electric field due to a combination of positive and negative charges.
Give the formula for determining flux from a charge at the centre of a cube.

• If \(q\) is at the centre of cube, \[\phi=\cfrac{q}{\varepsilon_{0}}\]
  • From each face of cube, \[\phi=\cfrac{q}{6 \varepsilon_{0}}\]
Give the formula for determining electric field due to a long straight wire.

Electric field due to a thin, infinitely long straight wire of uniform linear charge density \(\lambda\), \[E=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}\] where
\(r\) = perpendicular distance of the observation point from the wire
Give the formula for determining electric field due to an infinite sheet of uniform charge.
Electric field due to a thin non conducting infinite sheet of charge with uniform surface charge density \(\sigma\) is \[E=\frac{\sigma}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\]
Give the formula for determining electric field between two charged plane parallel sheets.
Electric field between two infinite thin plane parallel sheets of uniform surface charge density \(\sigma\) and \(-\sigma\) is \[E= \cfrac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}\]
Electric field intensity is a {{c1::vector}} quantity. (scalar/vector?)
If {{c1::\(q>0\)}}, then electric field is directed {{c2::away}} from source charge.
If {{c1::\(q<0\)}}, then electric field is directed {{c2::towards}} the source charge.
Dipole moment is a {{c1::vector}} quantity. (scalar/vector)
Dipole moment is directed from {{c1::negative to positive}} charge.
Dimensional formula of dipole moment is {{c1::\([ATL]\)}}.
When an electric dipole is parallel to electric field, it is in {{c1::stable}} equilibrium.
When an electric dipole is antiparallel to electric field, it is in {{c1::unstable}} equilibrium.
If a dipole is enclosed by a closed surface, flux \(\phi\) is equal to {{c1::zero}}.
The shape of Gaussian surface for a sphere or spherical shell : {{c1::concentric sphere}}.
The shape of Gaussian surface for a cylinder or an infinite rod : {{c1::coaxial cylinder}}.
The shape of Gaussian surface for a plate : {{c1::cube or a cuboid}}.
Define electric potential.

Electric potential at a point is defined as amount of work done in bringing a unit positive charge from infinity to that point. It is denoted by symbol \(V\), and has SI Unit \(V\).
\[V=\cfrac{W}{q}\]
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point, at a distance \(r\) from a point charge \(q\).
\[V=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}\]
Give the formula for determining electric potential due to a group of charges.

The electric potential at a point due to a group of charges is equal to the algebraic sum of the electric potentials due to individual charges at that point. \[V=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left(\cfrac{q_{1}}{r_{1}}+\cfrac{q_{2}}{r_{2}}+\cfrac{q_{3}}{r_{3}}+\ldots \cfrac{q_{n}}{r_{n}}\right)=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \cfrac{q_{i}}{r_{i}}\]
Give the formula and diagram for determining electric potential at any point due to an electric dipole.

The electric potential at a point \(P\) due to an electric dipole \[V=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\cfrac{p \cos \theta}{r^{2}}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{\vec{p} \cdot \hat{r}}{r^{2}}\]
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point lying on the axial line of a dipole.
When the point \(P\) lies on the axial line of dipole, that is, \(\theta=0^{\circ}\), then \[V=\cfrac{p}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}\]
Give the graph showing variation of electric potential at point with the distance of point from centre of a thin, uniformly charged spherical sphere.

*where
\(V\) = electric potential
\(R\) = radius of spherical shell
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of shell *
Give the relationship between electric field and electric potential.

\[\vec{E}=-\vec{\nabla} V\] where \(\vec{\nabla}=\left(\hat{i} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x}+\hat{j} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial y}+\hat{k} \cfrac{\partial}{\partial z}\right)\)
(\(-ve\) sign shows that the direction of \(\vec{E}\) is the direction of decreasing potential)
Give the formula for determining the electric potential energy of a system of two point charges.

\[U=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q_{1} q_{2}}{r_{12}}\] *where
\(r_{12}\) = distance between \(q_{1}\) and \(q_{2}\). *
Give the formula for determining the electric potential energy of a system of \(n\) point charges.

\[U=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \times \sum_{\text {all pairs}} \cfrac{q_{j} q_{k}}{r_{j k}}\] where
\(r_{jk}\) = distance between \(j\) and \(k\)
\(j>k\)
What are conductors?

Those substances which can easily allow electricity to pass through them are known as conductors. They have a large number of free charge carriers that are free to move inside the material.
e.g. : metals, human beings, earth etc.
List the basic electrostatic properties of a conductor. (any 3)

Basic electrostatics properties of a conductor are as follows:

  • Inside a conductor, electric field is zero.
  • At the surface of a charged conductor, electric field must be normal to the surface at every point.
  • The interior of a conductor can have no excess charge in the static situation.
  • Electric potential is constant throughout the volume of the conductor and has the same value (as inside) on its surface.
  • Electric field at the surface of a charged conductor is given by \(\vec{E}=\cfrac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}} \quad \hat{n}\)
Give the formula for determining electric field at the surface of a charged conductor.

\[\vec{E}=\cfrac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}} \quad \hat{n}\] where
\(\sigma\) = surface charge density
\(\hat{n}\) = unit vector normal to the surface in the outward direction
What is electrostatic shielding?
Electrostatic shielding is the phenomenon of protecting a certain region of space from external electric field.
What is a polar molecule?

• A polar molecule is one which the centres of positive and negative charges are separated (even when there no external field).
  • A polar molecule has a permanent dipole moment.
  • e.g. :
    • \(\ce{H2O}\)
    • \(\ce{HCl}\)
What is a non-polar molecule?

• A non-polar molecule is one in which the centres of positive and negative charges coincide.
  • A non polar molecule has no permanent dipole moment.
  • e.g. :
    • \(\ce{O2}\)
    • \(\ce{H2}\)
Define capacitance.

Capacitance of a capacitor is the ratio of charge given to the potential to which it is raised. It has SI unit farad (\(F\)). \[C= \cfrac{Q}{V}\] where
\(C\) = capacitance
\(Q\) = charge
\(V\) = potential
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of a spherical conductor.

is \[C=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R\] where
\(R\) = radius of sphere
How can we determine the capacitance of Earth?
Taking Earth to be a conducting sphere of radius \(6400 \space km\), its capacity will be \[C=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R=\cfrac{6.4 \times 10^{6}}{9 \times 10^{9}}=711 \quad \mu F\]
What is a capacitor?

A condenser or a capacitor is a device that stores electric charge.

  • It consists of two conductors separated by an insulator or dielectric.
  • The two conductors carry equal and opposite charges, \(\pm Q\).
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of an air filled parallel plate capacitor.

\[C=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d}\] where
\(A\) = area of each plate
\(d\) = separation between the two plates
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of an air filled spherical capacitor.

\[C=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \cfrac{a b}{b-a}\] where
\(a\) = inner radius
\(b\) = outer radius
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of an air filled cylindrical capacitor.

\[C=\cfrac{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} L}{\ln \left(\cfrac{b}{a}\right)}\] where
\(a\) = inner radius
\(b\) = outer radius
\(L\) = length
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor with a dielectric slab completely filling the space between the plates.

\[C=\cfrac{K \varepsilon_{0} A}{d}=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{r} A}{d}\] where
\(K\) = dielectric constant of dielectric slab
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor with a dielectric slab partially filling the space between the plates.

\[C=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d-t\left(1-\cfrac{1}{K}\right)}\] where
\(K\) = dielectric constant of dielectric slab
\(t\) = thickness of dielectric slab
Give the formula for determining the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor with a metallic conductor partially filling the space between the plates.

\[C=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{0} A}{d-t}\] where
\(t\) = thickness of metallic conductor
Give the formula for determining the equivalent capacitance of capacitors connected in series.
For \(n\) capacitors connected in series, the equivalent capacitance \(C_{S}\) is given by \[\cfrac{1}{C_{S}}=\cfrac{1}{C_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{C_{2}}+\ldots . +\cfrac{1}{C_{n}}\]
Give the formula for determining the equivalent capacitance of capacitors connected in parallel.
For \(n\) capacitors connected in parallel, the equivalent capacitance \(C_{P}\) is given by \[C_{P}=C_{1}+C_{2}+\ldots . +C_{n}\]
What is common potential?

When two capacitors charged to different potentials are connected by a conducting wire, charge flows from the one at higher potential to the other at lower potential till their potentials become equal. This equal potential is called common potential. \[V=\cfrac{\text { total charge }}{\text { total capacity }}=\cfrac{Q_{1}+Q_{2}}{C_{1}+C_{2}}=\cfrac{C_{1} V_{1}+C_{2} V_{2}}{C_{1}+C_{2}}\] where
\(V\) = common potential
Is there any loss of charge in the process of sharing of charges across capacitors?
There is absolutely no loss of charge.
Is there any loss of energy in the process of sharing of charges across capacitors?
Yes, some energy is lost tin the form of heat, given by  \[U_{1}-U_{2}=\cfrac{C_{1} C_{2}\left(V_{1}-V_{2}\right)^{2}}{2\left(C_{1}+C_{2}\right)}\]
Give the formula for determining the energy lost in the process of sharing charges between two capacitors.
Energy lost in form of heat is given by \[U_{1}-U_{2}=\cfrac{C_{1} C_{2}\left(V_{1}-V_{2}\right)^{2}}{2\left(C_{1}+C_{2}\right)}\]
Give the formula for determining the energy stored in a capacitor.

Work done in charging a capacitor gets stored in the capacitor in the form of its electric potential energy (\(U\)) and it is given by \[U=\cfrac{1}{2} C V^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} Q V=\cfrac{1}{2} \cfrac{Q^{2}}{C}\]
Define energy density.
The energy stored per unit volume in the electric field between the plates is known as energy density (\(u\)). \[u=\cfrac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{0} E^{2}\]
How is the potential difference affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery remains connected?

Potential difference between the plates remains constant, that is, \[V=V_{0}\]where
\(V_{0}\) = potential difference in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the capacitance affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery remains connected?

Capacitance \(C\) increases, that is, \[C=K C_{0}\]where
\(C_{0}\) = capacitance of the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the charge affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery remains connected?

Charge on a capacitor increases, that is, \[Q=K Q_{0}\]where
\(Q_{0}\) = charge stored in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the electric field affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery remains connected?

Electric field between the plates remains unchanged, that is, \[E=E_{0}\]where
\(E_{0}\) = electric field in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the energy stored affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery remains connected?

Energy stored in a capacitor increases, that is, \[U=K U_{0}\]where
\(U_{0}\) = energy stored in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the potential difference affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery is disconnected?

Potential difference between the plates decreases. that is, \[V=\cfrac{V_{0}}{K}\]where
\(V_{0}\) = potential difference in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the capacitance affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery is disconnected?

Capacitance \(C\) increases, that is, \[C=K C_{0}\]where
\(C_{0}\) = capacitance of the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the charge affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery is disconnected?

Charge remains unchanged, that is, \[Q=Q_{0}\]where
\(Q_{0}\) = charge stored in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the electric field affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery is disconnected?

Electric field between the plates decreases, that is, \[E=\cfrac{E_{0}}{K}\] where
\(E_{0}\) = electric field in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
How is the energy stored affected when a dielectric slab is introduced between the plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, and the charging battery is disconnected?

Energy stored in the capacitor decreases, that is,\[U=\cfrac{U_{0}}{K}\]where
\(U_{0}\) = energy stored in the air filled parallel plate capacitor
Electric potential is a {{c1::scalar}} quantity. (scalar/vector?)
The SI unit of electric potential is {{c1::volt (\(V\))}}.
The dimensional formula of electric potential is {{c1::\(\left[ ML ^{2} T ^{-3} A ^{-1}\right]\)}}.
The SI unit of electric potential energy is {{c1::joule (\(J\))}}.
Inside a conductor, electric field is {{c1::zero}}.
At the surface of a charged conductor, electric field must be {{c1::normal}} to the surface at every point.
The SI unit of capacitance is {{c1::farad (\(F\))}}.
The dimensional formula of capacitance is {{c1::\(\left[ M ^{-1} L ^{-2} T ^{4} A ^{2}\right]\)}}.
When capacitors are connected in {{c1::series}}, the {{c2::charge}} through each capacitor is same.
When capacitors are connected in {{c1::parallel}}, the {{c2::potential difference}} across each capacitor is same.
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point lying on the equatorial line of a dipole.
When the point \(P\) lies on the equatorial line of the dipole, that is, \(\theta=90^{\circ}\), then \[V=0\]
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point outside a uniformly charged spherical shell.

At a point outside the shell that is, \(r>R\), \[V=\cfrac{\sigma R^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0} r}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q}{r}\] where
\(\sigma\) = uniform surface charge density
\(R\) = radius of spherical shell
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of shell
\(q=4 \pi R^{2} \sigma\)
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point on the surface of a uniformly charged spherical shell.

At a point on the shell that is, \(r=R\), \[V=\cfrac{\sigma R}{\varepsilon_{0}}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q}{R}\] where
\(\sigma\) = uniform surface charge density
\(R\) = radius of spherical shell
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of shell
\(q=4 \pi R^{2} \sigma\)
<!--
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point outside a uniformly charged solid sphere.

At a point outside the sphere, that is, \(r>R\), \[V=\cfrac{\rho R^{3}}{3 \varepsilon_{0} r}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q}{r}\] where
\(\rho\) = uniform volume charge density
\(R\) = radius of solid sphere
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of solid sphere
\(q=\cfrac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho\)
What is an equipotential surface?
A surface on which the electric potential is constant is known as equipotential surface.
List the properties of an equipotential surface.

• Electric field lines are always perpendicular to an equipotential surface.
  • Work done in moving an electric charge from one point to another on an equipotential surface is zero.
  • Two equipotential surfaces can never intersect one another.
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point inside a uniformly charged solid sphere.

At a point inside the sphere, that is, \(r<R\), \[V=\cfrac{\rho}{3 \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{\left(3 R^{2}-r^{2}\right)}{2}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q\left(3 R^{2}-r^{2}\right)}{2 R^{3}}\] where
\(\rho\) = uniform volume charge density
\(R\) = radius of solid sphere
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of solid sphere
\(q=\cfrac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho\)
Give the formula for determining electric potential at a point on the surface of a uniformly charged solid sphere.

At a point on the sphere, that is, \(r=R\), \[V=\cfrac{\rho R^{2}}{3 \varepsilon_{0}}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q}{R}\] where
\(\rho\) = uniform volume charge density
\(R\) = radius of solid sphere
\(r\) = distance of point from the centre of solid sphere
\(q=\cfrac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho\)
What is the nature of magnetic field inside a solenoid?

• almost uniform
  • strong
  • is along the axis
Give the formula and diagram for magnetic field due to a straight current carrying conductor.

The magnetic field \(B\) at a point \(P\) due to a straight wire of finite length carrying current \(I\) at a perpendicular distance \(r\) is \[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I}{4 \pi r} \cdot [\sin \alpha+\sin \beta]\]

  • Special cases :
    • If the wire is of infinite length, and the point \(P\) lies near the centre of the straight wire, then \(\alpha=\beta=90^{\circ}\) \[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} \cdot 2 I}{4 \pi r}\]
    • If the wire is of infinite length and the point \(P\) lies near one end, then \(\alpha=\cfrac{\pi}{2}\) and \(\beta=0^{\circ}\) \[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I}{4 \pi r}\]
Define one Coulomb.
\(1 \space C\) is defined as the amount of charge transferred from a current of \(1 \space A\) flowing for \(1 \space sec\) through a cross-section of a conductor.
Describe the motion of a charged particle in a magnetic field, where velocity and magnetic field are perpendicular to each other.
A charged particle will move in a circle if \(v\) and \(B\) are perpendicular.
Plot magnetic field vs radius graph for a conducting wire.
Give the formula and diagram for magnetic field due to a straight solenoid.

• At any point inside the solenoid, \[B=\mu_{0} n I\] where
    \(n=\) number of turns per unit length
  • At the ends of the solenoid, \(B=\cfrac{1}{2} \mu_{0} n I\)
Give the formula and diagram for the magnetic field at the centre of a current carrying arc.
\[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} }{4 \pi} \cdot \cfrac{I \theta}{r}\]
{{c1::Magnetic}} force acts {{c2::perpendicular}} to both the {{c3::velocity and magnetic}} fields.
If velocity and magnetic field are {{c1::parallel (OR) antiparallel}}, the magnetic force is {{c2::zero}}.
Nature of the magnetic field {{c1::outside}} solenoid is {{c2::very weak and negligible}}.
A charged particle will move in a {{c1::circle}} if {{c2::\(v\) and \(B\)}} are {{c3::perpendicular}}.
What is a magnetic field?
It is a region or space around a magnet or current carrying conductor or a moving charges, in which its magnetic effect can be felt.
What is current sensitivity? Give it's formula.

It is defined as the deflection produced in the galvanometer, when unit current flows through it.\[I_{s}=\cfrac{\theta}{I}=\cfrac{N A B}{k}\]
The unit of current sensitivity is \(\operatorname{rad} A ^{-1}\) or \(\operatorname{div} A ^{-1}\)
What is voltage sensitivity? Give it's formula.

It is defined as the deflection produced in the galvanometer when a unit voltage is applied across the two terminals of the galvanometer. \[V_{s}=\cfrac{\theta}{V}=\cfrac{\theta}{I R}=\cfrac{N A B}{k R}\]
The unit of voltage sensitivity is \(rad \space V ^{-1}\) or \(\operatorname{div} V ^{-1}\).
Relation between current sensitivity and voltage sensitivity.
Give the formula for the magnetic field at the centre of a current carrying loop

The magnetic field at the centre of circular coil of radius \(r\), carrying current \(I\), is \[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I}{2 r}\]

  • For \(N\) turns of coil, \[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} N I}{2 r}\]
Give the formula for Lorentz force.
\[F =q( E + v \times B )\]
What is the potential energy on a current carrying loop?
\[U=-\vec{M} \cdot \vec{B}\]
Give the formula and the diagram for the magnetic field at the centre of a semi circular current carrying conductor.
\[B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I}{4 r}\]
Give the formula for the radius when charge is moving in a helical motion.
\[R = \cfrac{mV}{qB}\]
Give the formula for pitch when charge is moving in a helical motion.
\[P = 2 \pi \times \cfrac{ mv}{qB}\]
Give the formula and diagram for the force on a current carrying wire in an electric field.
\[\overrightarrow{ F }= I (\overrightarrow{l} \times \overrightarrow{ B })\]
Give the formula and diagram of the magnetic field at a point on an axis due to a circular loop.
\[B =B_{x} \space \hat{ i }=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I R^{2} }{2\left(x^{2}+R^{2}\right)^{\cfrac{3}{2} } } \space \hat{ i }\]
Give the formula of Biot Savart Law.

\[d B=k \cdot \cfrac{I \space d l \space \sin \theta}{r^{2} }\] where
\(K=\cfrac{\mu_{0} }{4 \pi}\)
Give the formula of the resistance of galvanometer converted to an ammeter.
Give the formula for the torque on a current carrying loop?

\[\tau=N I A B \space \sin \theta=M B \sin \theta\] where
Magnetic moment (\(M\)) \(=N I A\)
\(\theta\) = angle between the direction of magnetic field and normal to the plane of the coil
Give the formula for the work done on a current carrying loop,
\[w=u_{2}-u_{1}=-M B\left(\cos \theta_{2}-\cos \theta_{1}\right)\]
What is the working principle of a moving coil galvanometer?
It's based on the principle of a current carrying loop placed in a magnetic field experiencing a torque.
Give the formula for the value of the angle in a moving coil galvanometer.
\[\theta=\left(\cfrac{n B A}{k}\right) I\]
What is the right hand thumb rule?
Take the wire in your right hand, point thumb in the current direction, your fingers will curl in the magnetic field direction.
What is the force per unit length between two parallel conducting wires?
\[\cfrac{F}{l}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} I_{1} I_{2} }{2 \pi a}\]
Give the formula of magnetic field for a current carrying wire.
\[B =\cfrac{\mu_{0} i }{2 \pi a }\]
Give the formula of the magnetic flux for a coil.
\(\phi=N A B \cos \theta\)
Give the formula of the force on moving charges in an electric field
\[\overrightarrow{ F }= q (\overrightarrow{ v } \times \overrightarrow{ B })\]
How to convert a galvanometer into an ammeter?

A galvanometer can be converted into an ammeter of given range by connecting a suitable low resistance \(S\) called shunt in parallel to the given galvanometer, who's value is given by: \[S=\left(\cfrac{I_{g} }{I-I_{g} }\right) G\]
How do you convert a galvanometer into a voltmeter?
A galvanometer can be converted into voltmeter of given range by connecting a suitable resistance \(R\) in series with the galvanometer, whose value is given by: \[R=\cfrac{V}{I_{g} }-G\]

{{c1::\(1\) Ampere}} is defined as  {{c2::the value of current when 2 long parallel straight conductors, \(1\space m\) apart in vacuum, produce a force of \(2 \times 10^{-7} \space N \space m^{-1}\)}}.
If {{c1::velocity}} has a component along {{c2::\(B\)}}, the motion in a plane perpendicular to {{c3::\(B\)}} is a circular one, thereby producing a {{c4::helical}} motion.
Magnetic moment of a {{c1::planar loop}} is {{c2::\(\overrightarrow{ M }= NI \overrightarrow{ A }\)}}.
The SI unit of {{c1::magnetic field}} is {{c2::Tesla (\(T\))}}.
The SI unit of {{c1::magnetic moment}} is {{c2::\(A \space m^{2}\)}}.
The value of {{c1::\(\cfrac{\mu_{0} }{4 \pi}\)}} is {{c2::\(10^{-7} \quad T \space m \space A^{-1}\)}}.
For a charged particle to exhibit magnetism, it must be {{c1::in motion}}.
Parallel currents {{c1::attract}} and anti-parallel currents {{c2::repel}}.
Magnetic field is a {{c1::vector}} quantity. (scalar/vector?)
An {{c1::ideal}} voltmeter has {{c2::infinite}} {{c3::resistance}}.
An {{c1::ideal}} ammeter has {{c2::zero}} {{c3::resistance}}.
What are Maxwell's equations?

The basic principle of electromagnetism can be formulated in terms of four fundamental equations known as Maxwell's equations. They are as follows:

  • Gauss's Law for electrostatics: \[ \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{S}=\cfrac{q}{\varepsilon_{0} }\]
  • Gauss's Law for magnetism: \[\oint \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{S}=0\]
  • Faraday's Law of electromagnetic induction: \[\oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l}=\left( -\cfrac{d \phi_{B} }{d t} \right)\]
  • Maxwell-Ampere's circuital Law:\[\oint \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{l}=\mu_{0}\left[I+\varepsilon_{0} \cfrac{d \phi_{E} }{d t}\right]\]
Give the formula for Gauss's Law for electrostatics.
\[ \oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{S}=\cfrac{q}{\varepsilon_{0} }\]
Give the formula for Gauss's Law for magnetism.
\[\oint \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{S}=0\]
Give the formula for Faraday's Law of electromagnetic induction.
\[\oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{l}=\left( -\cfrac{d \phi_{B} }{d t} \right)\]
Give the formula for Maxwell-Ampere's circuital Law.
\[\oint \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{l}=\mu_{0}\left[I+\varepsilon_{0} \cfrac{d \phi_{E} }{d t}\right]\]
What are electromagnetic waves?

Electromagnetic waves are those waves in which there is a sinusoidal variation of electric and magnetic field at right angles to each other, as well as at right angles to the direction of wave propagation.
Give the formula for the electric field of a plane progressive electromagnetic wave.
\[E=E_{0} \sin (k z-\omega t)\]
Give the formula for the magnetic field of a plane progressive electromagnetic wave.
\[B=B_{0} \sin (k z-\omega t)\]
Relation between the amplitudes of electric and magnetic fields of EM waves in free space.
Give the formula for the speed of electromagnetic wave in free space.

\[c=\cfrac{E_{0} }{B_{0} }=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} } }=3 \times 10^{8} \quad m \space s^{-1}\] where
\(\mu_{0}\) = permeability of free space
\(\varepsilon_{0}\) = permittivity of free space
Give the formula for the speed of electromagnetic wave in a medium.

\[v=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{\mu \varepsilon} }\] where
\(\mu\) = permeability of medium
\(\varepsilon\) = permittivity of medium

  • it can be further written as \(v=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \mu_{r} \varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{r} } }=\cfrac{c}{\sqrt{\mu_{r} \varepsilon_{r} } }\), where \(c=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} } }\)
List the properties of electromagnetic waves.

• These waves do not carry any charge.
  • These waves are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields.
  • They travel with the speed of light \(\left(3 \times 10^{8} \quad m \space s ^{-1}\right)\) in vacuum.
  • The frequency of electromagnetic wave does not change when it goes from one medium to another but its wavelength changes.
  • These waves are transverse in nature, hence they can be polarised.
Do electromagnetic waves carry any charge?
These waves do not carry any charge.
Can electromagnetic waves be deflected by electric and magnetic fields?
These waves are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields.
How does the frequency and wavelength of an electromagnetic wave get affected when it goes from one medium to another?
The frequency of electromagnetic wave does not change when it goes from one medium to another, but its wavelength changes.
How can we bring about the production of electromagnetic waves?

• Maxwell showed that an electric charge oscillating harmonically with frequency \(\nu\) produces electromagnetic waves of the same frequency.
  • An electric dipole is a basic source of electromagnetic waves.
Give the formula for energy density of electric field in electromagnetic waves.
\[u_{E}=\cfrac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{0} E_{r m s}^{2}\]
Give the formula for energy density of magnetic field in electromagnetic waves.
Give the formula for average energy density of electromagnetic waves.
\[ u_{av} = u_{E}+u_{B} = \cfrac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{0} E_{r m s}^{2}+\cfrac{1}{2} \cfrac{B_{r m s}^{2} }{\mu_{0} }\]
Define intensity in terms of wave nature of electromagnetic radiation.

It is defined as the amount of light energy crossing per unit area per unit time, perpendicular to the direction of propagation of electromagnetic wave. \[I= u_{av} \times c=\cfrac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{0} E_{r m s}^{2} c\] SI unit is \(W m ^{-2}\) or \(J m ^{-2} s ^{-1}\)
What is the momentum of electromagnetic wave?

• An electromagnetic wave carries linear momentum.
  • Electromagnetic wave strikes the surface at normal incidence and transports a total energy \(U\) to the surface in a time \(t\). If the surface absorbs all the incident energy, the total momentum \(p\) transported to the surface is \[p=\cfrac{U}{c}\] (complete absorption)
  • If the surface is a perfect reflector, and incidence is normal, then the momentum transported to the surface is \[ p=\cfrac{2 U}{c}\] (complete reflection)
In electromagnetic wave, the electric and magnetic fields have the same {{c1::frequency}} and are in the same {{c2::phase}}.
Speed of propagation of electromagnetic waves : {{c1::\(3 \times 10^{8} \quad m \space s ^{-1}\) (speed of light)}}.
Electromagnetic waves are {{c1::transverse}} in nature, hence they can be {{c2::polarised}}.
An electromagnetic wave carries {{c1::linear}} momentum.
What is radiation pressure?

It is defined as the pressure exerted by the electromagnetic wave on a surface. \[\begin{aligned} P_{\text {radiation } } &=~\cfrac{I}{c} \quad \quad \text { (perfectly absorbing surface) } \\ P_{\text {radiation } } &=\cfrac{2 I}{c}\quad \quad \text { (perfectly reflecting surface) } \end{aligned}\] where
\(P_{\text {radiation } }\) = radiation pressure for normal incidence
\(I\) = intensity of the incident electromagnetic radiation
What is electromagnetic spectrum?
The orderly distribution of electromagnetic radiations according to their wavelength or frequency is known as electromagnetic spectrum.
Wavelength range of {{c1::radiowaves}} is {{c2::\(> \space 10^{-1}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::microwaves}} is {{c2::\(10^{-1}\) to \(10^{-3}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::infrared waves}} is {{c2::\(10^{-3}\) to \(7 \times 10^{-7}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::visible light}} is {{c2::\(7 \times 10^{-7}\) to \(4 \times 10^{-7}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::ultraviolet light}} is {{c2::\(4 \times 10^{-7}\) to \(1 \times 10^{-9}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::X-rays}} is {{c2::\(10^{-9}\) to \(10^{-12}\)}} \(m\)
Wavelength range of {{c1::Gamma rays}} is {{c2::\(< \space 1 \times 10^{-12}\)}} \(m\)
Frequency range of {{c1::radiowaves}} is {{c2::\(< \space 3 \times 10^{9}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::microwaves}} is {{c2::\(3 \times 10^{8}\) to \(3 \times 10^{11}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::infrared waves}} is {{c2::\(3 \times 10^{11}\) to \(4 \times 10^{14}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::visible light}} is {{c2::\(4 \times 10^{14}\) to \(8 \times 10^{14}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::ultraviolet light}} is {{c2::\(8 \times 10^{14}\) to \(8 \times 10^{16}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::X-rays}} is {{c2::\(1 \times 10^{16}\) to \(3 \times 10^{21}\)}} \(Hz\)
Frequency range of {{c1::Gamma rays}} is {{c2::\(> \space 3 \times 10^{21}\)}} \(Hz\)
{{c1::Radiowaves}} are produced by {{c2::rapid acceleration and deceleration of electrons in aerials.}}
{{c1::Microwaves}} are produced by {{c2::Klystron valve, Magnetron valve and Gunn diode}}.
{{c1::Infrared}} waves are produced by {{c2::vibration of atoms and molecules (de-excitation of atoms), hot bodies}}.
{{c1::Visible}} light is produced by {{c2::electrons in atoms, which emit light when moving from one energy level to a lower energy level}}.
{{c1::Ultraviolet}} light is produced by {{c2::inner shell electrons in atoms moving from one energy level to a lower level}}.
{{c1::X-rays}} are produced by {{c2::X-ray tubes, or bombarding a metal target by high speed electrons}}.
{{c1::Gamma}} rays are produced by {{c2::radioactive decay of the nucleus}}.
{{c1::Radio}}waves are detected by {{c2::reciever's aerials.}}
{{c1::Micro}}waves are detected by {{c2::point contact diodes}}.
{{c1::Infrared}} waves are detected by {{c2::Thermopiles, Bolometer, or infrared photographic film}}.
{{c1::Visible light}} waves are detected by {{c2::the eye, photocells, or photographic film}}.
{{c1::Ultraviolet light}} waves are detected by {{c2::photocells or photographic film}}.
{{c1::X-rays}} are detected by {{c2::photographic film or Geiger tubes}}.
{{c1::Gamma rays}} are detected by {{c2::photographic film or ionization chamber}}.
List a few uses of radio waves.
• used in satellite, radio and television communication
List a few uses of microwaves.

• used in long distance communication
  • used in radar systems used in aircraft navigation
  • microwave ovens are used for cooking and heating food
List a few uses of infrared rays.

• maintain the Earth's warmth
  • used to treat muscular pain
  • used in night vision devices during warfare, because they can pass through haze, fog and mist
  • used in remote switches of household electrical appliances
List a few uses of ultraviolet rays.

• water purification
  • eye surgery
  • cause tanning of skin
List a few uses of X-rays.

• used to study atomic structure
  • used in medical science for imaging of skeleton
  • used for security purposes (screening baggage)
List a few uses of Gamma rays.
• used in the treatment of cancer and tumours
In which directions do the electric and magnetic field vectors oscillate in an electromagnetic wave propagating along the \(x\)-axis?
When an electromagnetic wave is propagating along the \(x\) -axis, then electric field vector oscillates in \(y\) -axis and magnetic field vector oscillates in \(z\) -axis.
How are electromagnetic waves produced by oscillating charges?

• An oscillating or accelerated charge is supposed to be source of an electromagnetic wave,
  • An oscillating charge produces an oscillating electric field in space which further produces an oscillating magnetic field which in turn is a source of electric field.
  • These oscillating electric and magnetic field hence, keep on regenerating each other and an electromagnetic wave is produced.
The small ozone layer on top of the stratosphere is crucial for human survival. Why?

• The small ozone layer on the top of the atmosphere is crucial for human survival because it absorbs harmful ultraviolet radiations present in sunlight and prevents it from reaching the earth's surface.
  • These radiations can penetrate our skin and can cause harmful diseases like skin cancer.
Arrange the following electromagnetic waves in order of increasing frequency : Gamma-rays, Microwaves, Infrared rays and Ultraviolet rays
Microwaves < Infra-red rays < Ultraviolet rays < Gamma-rays.
Name the physical quantity which remains same for microwaves of wavelength \(1 mm\) and UV radiations of \(1600 ~A^{\circ}\) in vacuum.

• The speed in vacuum \(\left(i . e ., c=3 \times 10^{8} m s ^{-1}\right)\) remains same for both the given wavelengths.
  • It is because both microwaves and UV rays are electromagnetic waves.
How are radio waves produced?
Radio waves are produced by the accelerated motion of charges in conducting wires or oscillating electric circuits having inductor and capacitor.
Which type of electromagnetic wave has minimum wavelength?
Gamma rays.
Which type of electromagnetic wave has minimum frequency?
Microwaves.
Why are infrared waves often called heat waves? Explain.
Infrared waves incident on a substance increase the internal energy and hence the temperature of the substance. That is why they are called heat waves.
If the Earth did not have atmosphere, would its average surface temperature be higher or lower than what it is now?

• If the Earth did not have atmosphere, then there would be absence of green house effect of the atmosphere.
  • Due to this reason, the temperature of the earth would be lower than what it is now.
Why is it necessary in microwave ovens to select the frequency of microwaves to match the resonant frequency of water molecules?
The frequency of microwaves is selected to match the resonant frequency of water molecules, so that energy is transformed efficiently to the kinetic energy of the molecules.
Give the formula for determining the intensity of an electromagnetic wave in terms of wave nature.
\[I= u_{av} \times c=\cfrac{1}{2} \varepsilon_{0} E_{r m s}^{2} c\]
How can you show that electromagnetic waves carry both energy and momentum?

• Consider a plane perpendicular to the direction of propagation of the wave. An electric charge, on the plane will be set in motion by the electric and magnetic fields of e.m. wave, incident on this plane. This illustrates that electromagnetic waves carry energy and momentum.
  • Additionally, if light didn't carry energy and momentum, it wouldn't be able to heat stuff up or generate photocurrent in photocells.
What is the SI unit of the intensity of an electromagnetic wave?

children.name: Ch-09 Ray Optics and Optical Instruments

fields: What is refraction of light?

• When a ray of light passes from one medium to another, in which it has a different velocity, there occurs a change in the direction of propagation of light (except when it strikes the surface of separation of two media normally). This bending of a ray of light is known as refraction.
  • The angles made by the incident ray and the refracted ray with the normal to the separating surface at the point of incidence are known as the angle of incidence and of refraction respectively.
Give the laws of refraction.

The two laws of refraction are as follows:

  • The incident ray, the normal and the refracted ray all lie in the same plane.
  • The ratio of the sine of angle of incidence to the sine of angle of refraction for any two media is constant for a light of definite colour. This constant is denoted by \({ }^{1} \mu_{2}\) or \(\mu_{21}\) called the refractive index of the second medium with respect to the first. This is known as Snell's law. \[\cfrac{\sin i}{\sin r}={ }^{1} \mu_{2}\]
    where
    \(i=\) angle of incidence
    \(r=\) angle of refraction
    \(\mu_{21}\) = refractive index of medium \(2\) with respect to medium \(1\)
What is absolute refractive index?
Refractive index of a medium with respect to vacuum (or in practice, air) is known as absolute refractive index of the medium. \[\mu=\cfrac{c}{v}\]
Give the formula for Snell's Law.

\[\begin{aligned} \mu_{21}={ }^{1} \mu_{2}=&\cfrac{\mu_{2} }{\mu_{1} }=\cfrac{\sin i}{\sin r} \\ \text{(OR)} \space &\cfrac{\mu_{2} }{\mu_{1} }=\cfrac{\left(\cfrac{c}{v_{2} }\right)}{\left(\cfrac{c}{v_{1} }\right)}=\cfrac{v_{1} }{v_{2} }\end{aligned}\] where
\(c\) = the speed of light in air
\(v_{1}\),\(v_{2}\) = the speeds of light in medium 1 and medium 2 respectively
\(\mu_{21}\) = refractive index of medium \(2\) with respect to medium \(1\)
Draw the diagram for a light ray passing from a rarer to a denser medium.
When a light ray passes from a rarer to denser medium \(\left(\mu_{2}>\mu_{1}\right)\), it will bend towards the normal.
Draw the diagram for a light ray passing from a denser to a rarer medium.
When a light ray passes from a denser to rarer medium \(\left(\mu_{1}>\mu_{2}\right)\), it will bend away from the normal.
What happens when a light ray passes through a number of parallel media, the first and last media being the same?

• If a light ray passes through a number of parallel media and if the first and the last media are same. The emergent ray is parallel to the incident ray.
  • \[{ }^{1} \mu_{2}=\cfrac{\sin i_{1} }{\sin r_{1} }, \quad ^{2} \mu_{3}=\cfrac{\sin r_{1} }{\sin r_{2} }, \quad \text { and } \quad { }^{3} \mu_{1}=\cfrac{\sin r_{2} }{\sin i_{1} }\] Hence, \[{ }^{1} \mu_{2} \times{ }^{2} \mu_{3} \times{ }^{3} \mu_{1}=\cfrac{\sin i_{1} }{\sin r_{1} } \times \cfrac{\sin r_{1} }{\sin r_{2} } \times \cfrac{\sin r_{2} }{\sin i_{1} }=1\]
What is lateral shift?

When the medium is same on both sides of a glass slab, the emergent ray is parallel to the incident ray, but it suffers lateral displacement/shift with respect to the incident ray. This phenomenon is called lateral shift.
Relation between apparent depth and real depth.
\[\text { apparent depth }=\cfrac{\text { real depth } }{\text { refractive index }(\mu)}\]
Give the formula for apparent depth of an ink spot at the bottom of a glass slab.

\[d=t-\cfrac{t}{\mu}=t\left(1-\cfrac{1}{\mu}\right)\] where
\(d\) = distance the ink spot appears to be raised by
\(t\) = thickness of the glass slab (real depth)
\(\mu\) = refractive index of glass slab
Give the formula for apparent depth of a beaker filled with immiscible transparent liquids.

For a beaker filled with immiscible transparent liquids of refractive indices \(\mu_{1}, \mu_{2}, \mu_{3}\) and individual depths \(d_{1}, d_{2}, d_{3}\) respectively, then the apparent depth of the beaker: \[\text{Apparent depth} =\cfrac{d_{1} }{\mu_{1} }+\cfrac{d_{2} }{\mu_{2} }+\cfrac{d_{3} }{\mu_{3} }\]
What is total internal reflection?
Total internal reflection is the phenomenon of reflection of light into denser medium from the boundary of denser medium and rarer medium.
When a light ray passes from a rarer to denser medium, it will bend {{c1::towards}} the normal.
When a light ray passes from a denser to rarer medium, it will bend {{c1::away from}} the normal.
What factors does critical angle depend upon?

It depends on

  • nature of medium
  • wavelength of light
Give the formula and diagram for a diver in water looking outside from a pool.
\[r=d \cdot \tan i_{C}=\cfrac{d}{\sqrt{\mu^{2}-1} }\]
List a few applications of the phenomenon of total internal reflection.

• The working of optical fibre is based on the phenomenon of total internal reflection.
  • The brilliance of diamond is due to the phenomenon of total internal reflection.
  • Mirages in deserts are also caused due to total internal reflection.
Give the formula for refraction from a spherical surface, when the object is situated in rarer medium.

\[\cfrac{\mu_{2} }{v} -\cfrac{\mu_{1} }{u}=\cfrac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1} }{R}\] where
\(\mu_{1}\) = refractive index of rarer medium
\(\mu_{2}\) = refractive index of the spherical refracting surface
\(R\) = radius of curvature
Give the formula for refraction from a spherical surface, when the object is situated in denser medium.

\[\cfrac{\mu_{2} }{u} -\cfrac{\mu_{1} }{v} = \cfrac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1} }{R}\] where
\(\mu_{1}\) = refractive index of rarer medium
\(\mu_{2}\) = refractive index of the spherical refracting surface
\(R\) = radius of curvature
What is a lens?

A lens is a portion of a transparent refracting medium bound by two spherical surfaces or one spherical surface and the other plane surface. Lenses are divided into two classes :

  • Convex lens (OR) converging lens
  • Concave lens (OR) diverging lens
What is a convex lens?

When a lens is thicker in the middle than at the edges, it is known as convex lens or converging lens. They are of 3 types :

  • Double convex lens or biconvex lens
  • Plano convex lens
  • Concavo convex lens
What is a concave lens?

When a lens is thicker in the edges than in the middle, it is known as concave lens or diverging lens.

  • Double convex lens or biconcave lens
  • Plano concave lens
  • Convexo concave lens
Give Lens Maker's formula.

\[\cfrac{1}{f}=(\mu-1)\left(\cfrac{1}{R_{1} }-\cfrac{1}{R_{2} }\right)\] where
\(R_{1}\), \(R_{2}\) = radii of curvature of the two surfaces of the lens
\(\mu\) = refractive index of material of lens w.r.t. medium in which lens is placed

  • This formula is valid for thin lenses.
  • It is valid for both convex and concave lenses.
  • As per sign convention :
    • for a convex lens, \(R_{1}\) is positive and \(R_{2}\) is negative
    • for a concave lens, \(R_{1}\) is negative and \(R_{2}\) is positive.
Give Thin lens formula.

\[\cfrac{1}{v}-\cfrac{1}{u}=\cfrac{1}{f}\] where
\(u=\) distance of the object from thแบป รดptical centre of the lens
\(v\) - distance of the image from the optical centre of the lens
\(f=\) focal length of a lens

  • \(f\) is positive for converging or convex lens and \(f\) is negative for diverging or concave lens.
Give the formula for linear magnification.

\[m=\cfrac{\text { size of image }(I)}{\text { size of object }(O)}=\cfrac{v}{u}\]

  • \(m\) is positive for erect image and \(m\) is negative for inverted image.
Give the formula for determining the power of a lens.

\(P=\cfrac{1}{f \space \text{(in metres)} }\)

  • The SI unit of power of lens is dioptre. \(1 ~D =1 ~m ^{-1}\)
  • For a convex lens, \(P\) is positive.
  • For a concave lens, \(P\) is negative.
What is the SI unit of power of a lens?
The SI unit of power of lens is dioptre. \[1 ~D =1 ~m ^{-1}\]
Give the formula for the equivalent focal length for a combination of thin lenses in contact.

When a number of thin lenses of focal length \(f_{1}, f_{2}, \ldots\) etc., are placed in contact coaxially, the equivalent focal length \(F\) of the combination is given by :
\[\cfrac{1}{F}=\cfrac{1}{f_{1} }+\cfrac{1}{f_{2} }+\cfrac{1}{f_{3} }+\ldots\]
โฆ and the total power of the combination is given by
\[P=P_{1}+P_{2}+P_{3}+\ldots\]
Give the formula for the equivalent focal length for a combination of two thin lenses separated by a small distance.

When two thin lenses of focal lengths \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) are placed coaxially and separated by a distance \(d\), the focal length of a combination is given by \[\cfrac{1}{F}=\cfrac{1}{f_{1} }+\cfrac{1}{f_{2} }-\cfrac{d}{f_{1} f_{2} }\]
In terms of power, \[P=P_{1}+P_{2}-d P_{1} P_{2}\]
What is a prism?
A prism is a homogeneous, transparent medium enclosed by two plane surfaces inclined at an angle.
Give the general formulae related to refraction through a prism. Also, write the formula for finding minimum deviation when \(A\) and \(i\) are small.

\[\delta=i+e-A\] where \(A=r_{1}+r_{2}\)

  • When \(A\) and \(i\) are small, \(\delta=(\mu-1) ~A\)
Give the formula for finding refractive index of the material of prism.

\[\mu=\cfrac{\sin \left(\cfrac{A+\delta_{m}}{2}\right)}{\sin \left(\cfrac{A}{2}\right)}\] where
\(A\) = angle of prism
\(\delta_{m}\) = angle of minimum deviation

This is known as prism formula.
Explain the phenomena of formation of a rainbow.

• Rainbow is a beautiful arc of seven colours seen in the sky after rainfall.
  • The rainbow is an example of the dispersion of sunlight by the water drops in the atmosphere.
  • This phenomenon occurs due to combined effect of dispersion, refraction and reflection of sunlight by spherical water droplets of rain.
  • To observe the rainbow, back of observer must be towards the sun.
What is a simple microscope? Draw a neatly labeled diagram.

• A simple microscope, also known as magnifying glass or simple magnifier, consists of a convergent lens with object between its focus and optical centre and eye close to it.
  • The image formed by it is erect, virtual, enlarged and on same side of lens between object and infinity.
Give the formula for determining the magnifying power of a simple microscope in terms of angle subtended by image and object at the eye.
Magnifying power,\[M=\cfrac{\text { angle subtended by image at the eye } }{\text { angle subtended by the object at the eye } } =\cfrac{\tan \beta}{\tan \alpha}=\cfrac{\beta}{\alpha}\]
Critical angle for red light is {{c1::higher}} than that for blue light. (higher/lower?)
Critical angle for blue light is {{c1::lower}} than that for red light. (higher/lower?)
When the refractive index of the material of the lens is greater than that of the surrounding medium, the biconvex lens acts as a {{c1::converging}} lens. (converging/diverging?)
When the refractive index of the material of the lens is greater than that of the surrounding medium, the biconcave lens acts as a {{c1::diverging}} lens. (converging/diverging?)
When the refractive index of the material of the lens is smaller than that of the surrounding medium, the biconvex lens acts as a {{c1::diverging}} lens. (converging/diverging?)
When the refractive index of the material of the lens is smaller than that of the surrounding medium, the biconcave lens acts as a {{c1::converging}} lens. (converging/diverging?)
\(f\) is {{c1::positive}} for converging or convex lens. (positive/negative?)
\(f\) is {{c1::negative}} for diverging or concave lens. (positive/negative?)
List the essential conditions for total internal reflection to take place.

Two essential conditions for the phenomenon of total internal reflection are :

  • Light should travel from a denser to a rarer medium.
  • Angle of incidence in denser medium should be greater than the critical angle for the pair of media in contact.
Draw a neatly labeled diagram representing the phenomenon of lateral shift.
Give the formula for determining lateral shift for a ray passing through a glass slab.

\[d=t \cdot \cfrac{\sin (i-r)}{\cos r}\]where
\(d\) = lateral shift
\(t\) = thickness of the slab
What is critical angle? Give it's formula.
Critical angle is that angle of incidence for which the angle of refraction becomes \(90^{\circ}\). \[\sin i_{C}=\cfrac{1}{{ }^{R} \mu_{D} }\]
Give the formula for determining critical angle when the rarer medium is air or vacuum.
If the rarer medium is air or vacuum, then \[\sin i_{C}=\cfrac{1}{\mu} \cdot\]
What is the refracting angle in a prism?
The angle between the two refracting surfaces in a prism are known as the refracting angle or the angle of prism (\(A\)).
What is the angle of deviation in a prism?
The angle between the incident ray and the emergent ray in a prism is known as the angle of deviation (\(\delta\)).
Give the formulae related to refraction through a prism when the arrangement is in a position of minimum deviation.

In a position of minimum deviation,
\(\delta=\delta_{m}\), \(\quad i=e\), and \(\quad r_{1}=r_{2}=r\)
\(\therefore \quad i=\left(\cfrac{A+\delta_{m} }{2}\right)\) and \(r=\cfrac{A}{2}\)
Draw a well-labeled diagram representing the refraction of light through a prism.
Give the formula for determining the magnifying power of a simple microscope when image is formed at the least distance of distance vision.
When image is formed at LDDV, \[M=1+\cfrac{D}{f}\]
Give the formula for determining the magnifying power of a simple microscope when image is formed at infinity.
When image is formed at infinity. \[M=\cfrac{D}{f}\]
Give the formula for determining the value of absolute refractive index.
\[\mu=\cfrac{c}{v}=\cfrac{\text { speed of light in vacuum } }{\text { speed of light in medium } }\]
Give the formula for determining the resolving power of a microscope.

\[R.P. = \cfrac{1}{d}=\cfrac{2 \mu \sin \theta}{\lambda}\] where
\(\mu\) = refractive index of the medium between object and objective lens
\(\theta\) = half the angle of cone of light from the point object
\(d\) = limit of resolution of microscope
\(\mu \sin \theta\) = numerical aperture.
What is a wavefront?

The locus of all particles of the medium vibrating in the same phase at a given instant is known as wavefront.
Depending on the shape of sources of light, wavefront can be of three types :

  • Spherical wavefront
  • Cylindrical wavefront
  • Plane wavefront
What is a spherical wavefront?
When the source of light is a point source, the wavefront is spherical.
What is a cylindrical wavefront?
When the source of light is linear, the wavefront is cylindrical.
What is a plane wavefront?
When the point source or linear source of light is at very large distance, a small portion of spherical or cylindrical wavefront appears to be plane. Such a wavefront is known as plane wavefront.
State Huygen's principle.

According to Huygens principle,

  • Every point on given wavefront (primary wavefront) acts as a fresh source of new disturbance, called secondary wavelets.
  • The secondary wavelets spread out in all the directions with the speed of light in the medium.
  • A surface touching these secondary wavelets tangentially in the forward direction at any instant gives the new (secondary) wavefront at that instant.
What is a coherent source of light?
The sources of light, which emit continuous light waves of the same wavelength, same frequency and in same phase or having a constant phase difference are known as coherent sources.
What is an incoherent source of light?
Two sources of light which do not emit light waves with a constant phase difference are called incoherent sources.
What do we mean by interference of light?

It is the phenomenon of redistribution of energy on account of superposition of light waves from two coherent sources.
Interference pattern produce points of maximum and minimum intensity :

  • Points where resultant intensity is maximum, interference is said to be constructive.
  • Points where resultant intensity is minimum, interference is said to be destructive.
Give the formula for determining resultant amplitude a point caused due to interference of waves of two coherent sources.

\[R=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+2 a b \cos \phi}\] where
\(a, b\) = amplitudes of interfering waves due to two coherent sources
\(\phi\) = constant phase difference between the two waves at any point \(P\)
\(R\) = resultant amplitude at \(P\)
Give the formula for determining resultant intensity caused due to interference of waves of two coherent sources.

\[I= I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2} } \cos \phi\] where
\(I\) = resultant intensity

  • When \(\cos \phi=1\),
    \(I_{\max }=\left(\sqrt{I_{1} }+\sqrt{I_{2} }\right)^{2}\)
  • When \(\cos \phi=-1\)
    \(I_{\min }=\left(\sqrt{I_{1} }-\sqrt{I_{2} }\right)^{2}\)
  • \(\therefore \quad\cfrac{I_{\max } }{I_{\min} }=\cfrac{\left(\sqrt{I_{1} }+\sqrt{I_{2} }\right)^{2} }{\left(\sqrt{I_{1} }-\sqrt{I_{2} }\right)^{2} }\)
List the conditions for sustained interference of light.

• The two sources should continuously emit waves of the same wavelength or frequency.
  • The amplitudes of waves from two sources should preferably be equal.
  • The waves emitted by the two sources should either be in phase or should have a constant phase difference.
  • The two sources must lie very close to each other.
  • The two sources should be very narrow.
Explain Young's double slit experiment.

Young's double slit experiment was the first to demonstrate the phenomenon of interference of light. Using two slits illuminated by monochromatic light source, he obtained bright and dark bands of equal width placed alternately. These were called interference fringes.
What are interference fringes?
In Young's double slit experiment, the bright and dark bands of equal width placed alternately are called interference fringes.
Give the formula for determining path difference in constructive interference in Young's double slit experiment.

For constructive interference (formation of bright fringes), \[x_{n}=n \lambda \cfrac{D}{d}\] where
\(x_{n}=\) distance of \(n^{\text {th } }\) bright fringe from the centre
\(D=\) distance of slits from the screen
\(d=\) distance between two slits
\(n=0\); for central bright fringe
\(n=1\); for first bright fringe
\(n=2\); for second bright fringe (and so on)
Give the formula for determining path difference in destructive interference in Young's double slit experiment.

For destructive interference (formation of dark fringes), \[x_{n}=(2 n-1) \cfrac{\lambda D}{2 d}\] where
\(x_{n}=\) distance of \(n^{\text {th } }\) dark fringe from the centre
\(D=\) distance of slits from the screen
\(d=\) distance between two slits
\(n=1\); for first dark fringe
\(n=2\); for second dark fringe (and so on)
What is fringe width?
The distance between any two consecutive bright or dark fringes is known as fringe width.
Give the formula for determining fringe width.
\[\beta=\cfrac{\lambda D}{d}\]
Give the formula for determining angular fringe width.
\[\theta=\cfrac{\beta}{D}=\cfrac{\lambda}{d}\]

If \(W_{1}\) and \(W_{2}\) are widths of two slits, \(I_{1}\) and \(I_{2}\) are intensities of light coming from two slits, \(a\) and \(b\) are the amplitudes of light from these slits, then what is the value of \(\cfrac{W_{1} }{W_{2} }\)?

If \(W_{1}\) and \(W_{2}\) are widths of two slits, \(I_{1}\) and \(I_{2}\) are intensities of light coming from two slits, \(a\) and \(b\) are the amplitudes of light from these slits, then what is the value of \(\cfrac{I_{\max } }{I_{\min } }\)?
What happens to fringe width when the entire apparatus of Young's double slit experiment is immersed in a medium?

When entire apparatus of Young's double slit experiment is immersed in a medium of refractive index \(\mu\), then fringe width becomes \[\beta^{\prime}=\cfrac{\lambda^{\prime} D}{d}=\cfrac{\lambda D}{\mu d}=\cfrac{\beta}{\mu}\]
What happens when a thin transparent plate is placed in the path of one of the interfering waves in Young's double slit experiment?

When a thin transparent plate of thickness \(t\) and refractive index \(\mu\) is placed in the path of one of the interfering waves, fringe width remains unaffected but the entire pattern shifts by \[ \Delta x=(\mu-1) t \cdot \cfrac{D}{d}=(\mu-1) t \cdot \cfrac{\beta}{\lambda}\]
This shifting is towards the side in which transparent plate is introduced.
What is diffraction of light?
Diffraction is the phenomenon of bending of light around corners of an obstacle or aperture in the path of light.
What is the condition for \(n^{\text {th } }\) secondary maximum in diffraction of light due to a single slit?

\[\text{Path difference} =a \sin \theta_{n}=(2 n+1) \cfrac{\lambda}{2}\]
where
\(n\) = \(1,2,3, \ldots\)
\(a\) = width of single slit
What is the condition for \(n^{\text {th } }\) secondary minimum in diffraction of light due to a single slit?

\[\text{Path difference} =a \sin \theta_{n}=n \lambda\]
where
\(n\) = \(1,2,3, \ldots\)
\(a\) = width of single slit
Give the formula for determining the width of central maximum in single slit diffraction.
\[\text{Width of central maximum }=\cfrac{2 \lambda D}{a}\]
Give the formula for determining the width of secondary maximum or minima in single slit diffraction.

\[\beta=\cfrac{\lambda D}{a}\]
where
\(\beta\) = width of secondary maxima or minima
\(a\) = width of slit
\(D\) = distance of screen from the slit
Give the formula for determining the angular fringe width of central maximum in single slit diffraction.
\[\text{Angular fringe width of central maximum } = \cfrac{2 \lambda}{a}\]
Give the formula for determining the angular fringe width of secondary maximum or minima in single slit diffraction.
\[\text{Angular fringe width of secondary maxima or minima }=\cfrac{\lambda}{a}\]
What is Fresnel distance?
It is the minimum distance a beam of light has to travel before its deviation from straight line path becomes significant.
Give the formula for determining Fresnel distance.
\[Z_{F}=\cfrac{a^{2} }{\lambda}\] where \(Z_F\) = Fresnel distance
What is resolving power?

Resolving power is the ability of an optical instrument to produce distinctly separate images of two close objects. (i.e. it is the ability of the instrument to resolve or to to see as separate, the images of two close objects)
What is limit of resolution?

The minimum distance between two objects which can just be seen as separate by the optical instrument is known as the limit of resolution of the instrument.

  • Smaller the limit of resolution of the optical instrument, greater is its resolving power and vice-versa.
What is Rayleigh's criterion of limiting resolution?
According to Rayleigh, two nearby images are said to be resolved if the position of the central maximum of one coincides with the first secondary minimum of the other and vice versa.
What do we mean by resolving power of a microscope? Give it's formula.

Resolving power of a microscope is defined as the reciprocal of the minimum distance \(d\) between two point objects, which can just be seen through the microscope as separate. \[R.P. = \cfrac{1}{d}=\cfrac{2 \mu \sin \theta}{\lambda}\]
Define resolving power of a telescope.

It is defined as reciprocal of the smallest angular separation \((d \theta)\) between two distant objects, whose images are just seen in the telescope as separate. \[R.P. =\cfrac{1}{d \theta}=\cfrac{D}{1.22 \lambda}\]
Give the formula for determining the resolving power of a telescope.

\[R.P. =\cfrac{1}{d \theta}=\cfrac{D}{1.22 \lambda}\] where
\(D\) = diameter or aperture of the objective lens of the telescope
\(d \theta\) = limit of resolution of telescope
What does polarisation of light mean?
The phenomenon of restricting the vibrations of light (electric vector) in a particular direction, perpendicular to direction of wave motion is known as polarisation of light.
What is angle of polarisation?
The angle of incidence for which an ordinary light is completely polarised in the plane of incidence when it gets reflected from a transparent medium is called angle of polarisation.
State the Law of Malus.

Malusโ law states that the intensity of plane-polarized light that passes through an analyzer varies as the square of the cosine of the angle between the plane of the polarizer and the transmission axes of the analyzer. \[I \propto \cos ^{2} \theta\]
State Brewster's law.

According to Brewster's law, when unpolarised light is incident at polarising angle (\(i_{p}\)) on an interface separating a rarer medium from a denser medium of refractive index \(\mu\), such that \[\mu=\tan i_{p}\] โฆthen light is reflected in the rarer medium is completely polarised. The reflected and refracted rays are perpendicular to each other.
{{c1::Smaller}} the limit of resolution of the optical instrument, {{c2::greater}} is its resolving power.
{{c1::Greater}} the limit of resolution of the optical instrument, {{c2::smaller}} is its resolving power.

children.name: Ch-11 Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

fields: Define electron emission?

• It is the phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of a metal.
  • can be obtained from the following physical processes :
    • Thermionic emission
    • Photoelectric emission
    • Field emission or cold cathode emission
Define work function.

Work function is the minimum energy needed by an electron to come out from the metal surface. \[\phi_{0}=W_0=h \nu_{0}=\cfrac{h c}{\lambda_{0} }\] where
\(\phi_{0}\) (OR) \(W_{0}\) = Work function, measured in electron volt \(( eV )\)
What is thermionic emission?
It is the phenomenon of emission of electrons from the metal surface when heated suitably.
What is photoelectric emission?
It is the phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of metal when light radiations of suitable frequency fall on it.
What is field emission or cold cathode emission?
It is the phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of a metal under the application of a strong electric field.
Define photoelectric effect.
It is the phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of metals, when light radiations of suitable frequency fall on them.
The phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of a metal under the application of a strong electric field is known as {{c1::field emission or cold cathode emission}}.
The phenomenon of {{c1::field emission}} is also known as {{c2::cold cathode emission}}.
The phenomenon of emission of electrons from the surface of metals, when light radiations of suitable frequency fall on them is known as {{c1::photoelectric effect}}.
List the laws of photoelectric emission.

For a given metal and frequency of incident radiation:

  • the number of photoelectrons ejected per second is directly proportional to the intensity of the incident light
  • for a given metal, there exists a certain minimum frequency of the incident radiation below which no emission of photoelectrons takes place. This frequency is known as threshold frequency
  • above the threshold frequency, the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron is independent of the intensity of incident light but depends only upon the frequency (or wavelength) of the incident light.
  • the photoelectric emission is an instantaneous process. The time lag between the incidence of radiation and emission of photoelectrons is very small, less than \(10^{-9}\) seconds.
What is threshold frequency?
For a given metal, there exists a certain minimum frequency of the incident radiation below which no emission of photoelectrons takes place. This frequency is known as threshold frequency.
What factors does photoelectric current depend on?

It depends on:

  • intensity of incident light
  • potential difference applied between the two electrodes
Draw graph showing the effect of intensity of light on photoelectric current.
What is stopping potential?

The minimum retarding potential applied to anode plate with respect to cathode plate, which is just capable of stopping photoelectric current, is known as stopping potential or cut off potential. It is denoted by \(V_{0}\).
\[K_{\max }=e V_{0}=\cfrac{1}{2} m v_{\max }^{2}\] where
\(e\) = charge on the photoelectron
\(V_{0}\)= stopping potential
\(m\) = mass of photoelectron
\(v_{\max }\) = maximum velocity of emitted photoelectrons
Variation of stopping potential with frequency of incident radiation.
Variation of photocurrent with collector plate potential for different intensity of incident radiation.
Variation of photocurrent with collector plate potential for different frequencies of incident radiation.
What is Einstein's photoelectric equation?

• If a light of frequency \( u\) is incident on a photosensitive material having work function \(\left(\phi_{0} ight)\), then maximum kinetic energy of the emitted electron is given as \[ egin{aligned} &K_{\max } =h u -\phi_{0} \ \implies &K_{\max } = h \left( u- u_{0} ight) =h c\left(\cfrac{1}{\lambda}-\cfrac{1}{\lambda_{0} } ight) = e V_{0} \end{aligned}\] where
    \( u=\) frequency
    \( u_{0}=\) threshold frequency
    \(\lambda_{0}=\) threshold wavelength
    \(\lambda=\) incident wavelength
    \(V_{0}\)= stopping potential
  • Einstein's photoelectric equation is in accordance with the law of conservation of energy
Give a short note on the dual nature of radiation.

• Wave theory of electromagnetic radiation explains the phenomenon of interference, diffraction and polarisation
  • Particle nature of light explains photoelectric effect
  • hence, we assume light exhibits dual nature
What are photons?
The packets of energy (or energy particles) which are emitted by a source of radiation are called photons.
Formula for the energy of a photon.

\[E=h \nu=\cfrac{h c}{\lambda}\] where
\(E=\) energy of photon
\(\nu=\) frequency
\(\lambda=\) wavelength
\(h=\) Planck's constant
\(c=\) speed of the light
Formula for the momentum of a photon.

\[p=\cfrac{E}{c}=\cfrac{h \nu}{c}\] where
\(p=\)momentum of photon
\(\nu=\) frequency
\(\lambda=\) wavelength
\(h=\) Planck's constant
\(c=\) speed of the light
Formula for moving mass of a photon.

\[m=\cfrac{E}{c^{2} }=\cfrac{h \nu}{c^{2} }\] where
\(m=\)moving mass of photon
\(E=\) energy of photon
\(c=\) speed of the light
\(h=\) Planck's constant
\(\nu=\) frequency
{{c1::Stopping potential}} is also known as {{c2::cut off potential}}.
The rest mass of photon is {{c1::zero}}.
Above the threshold frequency, the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron is {{c1::independent of}}  the intensity of incident light.
Above the threshold frequency, the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron depends on {{c1::the frequency (or wavelength)}} of incident light.
The time lag between the incidence of radiation and emission of photoelectrons is {{c1::\(10^{-9}\) seconds}}.
Can photons be affected by electric/magnetic fields?
No, photons are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields.
Formula for number of photons emitted per second from a lamp of power \(P\)
\[n=\cfrac{P}{h \nu}=\cfrac{P \lambda}{h c}\]
What are de-Broglie waves (or Matter waves)?

• Reasoning that radiation and matter should be symmetrical in nature, Louis Victor de Broglie attributed a wave like character to matter (material particles).
  • Therefore, the waves associated with moving material particles are known as matter waves or de Broglie waves.
Give the formula of de Broglie wavelength in terms of momentum.

\[\lambda=\cfrac{h}{p}=\cfrac{h}{m v}\] where
\(m\) = the mass of the particle
\(v\) = velocity of the particle
\(p\) = momentum of the particle
Give the formula of de Broglie wavelength in terms of kinetic energy.
\[\lambda=\cfrac{h}{\sqrt{2 m K} }\]
Give the formula of de Broglie wavelength when a particle with charge \(q\) is accelerated through a potential difference \(V\).
\[\lambda=\cfrac{h}{\sqrt{2 m q V} }\]
Give the formula of de Broglie wavelength for an electron.
\[\lambda=\left(\cfrac{150}{V}\right)^{\cfrac{1}{2} } A^\circ\]
Give the formula of de Broglie wavelength for a gas molecule.

\[\lambda=\cfrac{h}{\sqrt{3 m k T} }\] where
\(m\) = mass
\(T\) = temperature (in \(K\))
\(k\) = Boltzmann constant
In a photon-particle collision (such as photon-electron collision), the total energy and total momentum are {{c1::conserved}}.
de-Broglie wavelength is {{c1::independent}} of the charge and nature of the material particle.
Define Threshold Frequency.

Threshold frequency (\(\nu_{0}\)) is defined as the minimum frequency of incident radiation below which the photoelectric emission stops
altogether.
Give the formula for the momentum of a particle in terms of it's kinetic energy.
\[p=\sqrt{2 m K}\]
Identify the surface would have greater value of work function in the stopping potential versus frequency graph.
\(M_{2}\) has greater value of work function, Since it has higher value of threshold frequency.
Which metal has smaller threshold wavelength, \(P\) or \(Q\)?
Metal \(Q\) has smaller threshold wavelength.
Explain why : "In photoelectric effect,  the photoelectric current increases as the intensity of monochromatic radiation incident on a photosensitive surface is increased".
Since photoelectric current is directly proportional to the number of photoelectrons emitted per second, on increasing intensity, more photoelectrons will be emitted.
Identify the pairs of curves that correspond to different materials, but same intensity of incident radiation.

• Since the value of stopping potential for the pair of curves ( 1 and 2 ) and \((3\) and 4\()\) are the same hence curves 1 and 2 correspond to one material while curves 3 and 4 represent another material.
  • The pairs of curves ( 1 and 3 ) and \((2\) and 4 ) correspond to different materials but same intensity of incident radiation as the saturation current depends upon intensity and not on material.
Draw a graph showing variation of photocurrent with the anode potential of a photocell.
How can we determine the value of Planck's constant from the graph?
Slope of the line \(=\cfrac{\Delta V}{\Delta \nu}=\cfrac{h}{e} \quad[\because e \Delta V=h \Delta \nu]\) - which is a constant quantity, and doesn't depend on nature of metal surface.
If the distance between the light source and the surface of a metal is increased, how will the stopping potential for the electrons emitted from it be effected?
Stopping potential only depends on the frequency of incident light. If distance increases, it does not affect the stopping potential.
What features of photoelectric effect can't be explained by wave theory of light?

• The instantaneous emission of electrons.
  • The existence of threshold frequency for a metal surface.
Draw a graph between the frequency of incident radiation and the maximum kinetic energy of the electrons emitted from the surface of a photosensitive material.
How can work function be determined from the graph?
Work function is given by the intercept of line on the kinetic energy axis.
Why is the slope of both the lines same in given graph?

Slope of line \(=\cfrac{\Delta V}{\Delta \nu} =\cfrac{h}{e} \quad[\because e \Delta V=h \Delta \nu]\)
It is a straight line because it's a constant quantity and does not depend an nature of metal surface.
Why is wave theory of electromagnetic radiation not able to explain photoelectric effect?

• According to wave theory, the kinetic energy of photoelectrons must depend on the intensity of incident light; but according to experimental observations, the kinetic energy of photoelectrons does not depend on the intensity of incident light.
  • According to wave theory, the light of any frequency can emit electrons from metallic surface provided the intensity of light be sufficient to provide necessary energy tor emission of electrons, but according to experimental observations, the light of frequency less than threshold frequency can not emit electrons; whatever be the intensity of incident light.
  • According to wave theory, the energy transferred by light waves will be distributed uniformly to all electrons present in the illuminated surface.
