Therefore, electrons will take some time to collect the necessary energy for their emission. But experimental observations show that the emission of electrons take place instantaneously after the light is incident on the metal; whatever be the intensity of light.
What is the value of \(hc\) in the formula \(E=\cfrac{h c}{\lambda}\)?
Write three basic properties of photons which are used to obtain einstein's photoelectric equation.

Einstein's photoelectric equation is \(K_{\max }=h \nu-\phi_{0}\). The main features of photons used to obtain it are as follows:

  • In the interaction of photons with free electrons, the entire energy of photon is absorbed.
  • Energy of photon is directly proportional to frequency.
  • In photon electron collision, the total energy and momentum remain constant.
Give the formula for determining intensity in terms of photon picture of electromagnetic radiation.

\[I=\cfrac{\text { Energy of photons } }{\text { area } \times \text { time } }=\cfrac{n \times h \nu}{A \times t}\] where
\(n\) = number of photons incident normally on crossing area \(A\) in time \(t\)
Draw a graph showing the variation of linear momentum of a charged particle with it's de Broglie wavelength.
\[p=\cfrac{h}{\lambda} \Rightarrow p \propto \cfrac{1}{\lambda}\]
Draw a plot showing the variation of de Broglie wavelength of electron with its kinetic energy.

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda &=\cfrac{h}{p}=\cfrac{h}{\sqrt{2 m K} } \\ \implies \lambda^{2} K &= \text{constant} \end{aligned}\] where
\(K\) = kinetic energy
Draw a plot showing the variation of de Broglie wavelength of electron with the square root of it's accelerating potential.
\(\lambda=\cfrac{\sqrt{150} }{\sqrt{ V } } ~A^{\circ}\) \(\implies \lambda \sqrt{V}=\) constant
What is the relation between the mass of a proton and the mass of an alpha particle?
What is the relation between the charge of a proton and the charge of an alpha particle?
For a given frequency, photoelectric current is {{c1::directly proportional  to}} intensity.
For a given frequency, stopping potential is {{c1::independent of the}} intensity.
Moving a light source closer to a surface causes {{c1::increase}} in intensity of light on the surface. (increase/decrease)?
Moving a light source farther from a surface causes {{c1::decrease}} in intensity of light on the surface. (increase/decrease)?
{{c1::Photoelectric}} effect shows the {{c2::quantum}} nature of electromagnetic radiation.
For same accelerating potential, a proton and a deutron have same {{c1::kinetic}} energy.
Mass of a deutron is {{c1::more}} than that of a proton. (more/less?)
Mass of a proton is {{c1::less}} than that of a deutron. (more/less?)
The resolving power of an electron microscope is {{c1::much greater}} than that of an optical microscope. (greater/smaller?)
The resolving power of an optical microscope is {{c1::much smaller}} than that of an electron microscope. (greater/smaller?)
Draw a graph of Rutherford's \(\alpha\)-scattering experiment showing number of deflected particles versus angle of deflection.
Give formula for number of \(\alpha\)-particles scattered pet unit area in Rutherford's \(\alpha\)-scattering experiment.

\[N(\theta) \propto \cfrac{1}{\sin ^{4}\left(\cfrac{\theta}{2}\right)}\] where
\(N(\theta)\) = number of \(\alpha\) particles scattered per unit area
\(\theta\) = scattering angle
What is impact parameter?

Impact parameter \((b)\) is defined as the perpendicular distance of the initial velocity vector of the alpha particle from the centre of the nucleus, when the particle is far away from the nucleus of the atom. \[b=\cfrac{Z e^{2} \cdot \cot \left(\cfrac{\theta}{2}\right)}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} K}\]
What is the distance of closest approach?
At the distance of closest approach, whole kinetic energy of the alpha particles is converted into potential energy. \[r_{0}=\cfrac{2 Z e^{2} }{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} K}\]
Give Rutherford's nuclear model of the atom.

According to this model, the entire positive charge and most of the mass of the atom is concentrated in a small volume known as the nucleus with electrons revolving around it just as planets revolve around the sun.
List the postulates of Bohr's model of the atom.

• An electron can revolve around the nucleus only in certain allowed circular orbits of definite energy and in these orbits, it does not radiate. These orbits are known as stationary orbits.
  • Angular momentum of the electron in a stationary orbit is an integral multiple of \(\cfrac{h}{2 \pi}\). \[ L = \cfrac{n h}{2 \pi}\] This is known as Bohr's quantization condition.
  • The emission of radiation takes place when an electron makes a transition from a higher to a lower orbit. The frequency of the radiation is given by \[v=\cfrac{E_{2}-E_{1} }{h}\]
What are stationary orbits?
An electron can revolve around the nucleus only in certain allowed circular orbits of definite energy and in these orbits, it does not radiate. These orbits are known as stationary orbits.
What is Bohr's quantisation condition?

Bohr's quantisation condition states' that angular momentum of the electron in a stationary orbit is an integral multiple of \(\cfrac{h}{2 \pi}\) \[\begin{aligned} L &= \cfrac{n h}{2 \pi} \\ \implies m v r &= \cfrac{n h}{2 \pi} \end{aligned}\]
Give the formula for finding frequency of radiation emitted when an electron makes a transition from a higher to a lower orbit.

\[v=\cfrac{E_{2}-E_{1} }{h}\] where
\(E_{2}\) = energy of the electron in higher orbit
\(E_{1}\) = energy of the electron in lower orbit
Give Bohr's formula for finding the radius of the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} r_{n} &= \cfrac{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} n^{2} h^{2} }{4 \pi^{2} m Z e^{2} } \\ \\ &=0.53 \times \cfrac{ n^{2} }{Z} \quad A^{\circ} \end{aligned}\] where
\(r_n\) = radius of \(n^{th}\) orbit
Give Bohr's formula for finding the velocity of electron in the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} v_{n} &= \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} } \cdot \cfrac{2 \pi Z e^{2} }{n h} \\ &= (2.2 \times 10^{6}) \cdot \cfrac{ Z }{n} \quad m s^{-1} \end{aligned}\] where
\(v_n\) = velocity of the electron in the \(n^{\text {th } }\) orbit
Give Bohr's formula for finding the kinetic energy of electron in the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} K_{n} = \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} } \cdot  \cfrac{Z e^{2} }{2 r_{n} } &=\left( \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} }\right)^{2} \cdot  \cfrac{2 \pi^{2} m e^{4} Z^{2} }{n^{2} h^{2} } \\ \\ &= (13.6) \times \cfrac{ Z^{2} }{n^{2} } \quad eV \end{aligned}\]
Give Bohr's formula for finding the potential energy of electron in the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} U_{n} = - \left ( \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} } \right) \cdot  \cfrac{Z e^{2} }{r_{n} } &=-\left( \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} }\right)^{2} \cdot  \cfrac{4 \pi^{2} m e^{4} Z^{2} }{n^{2} h^{2} } \\ \\ &= (- 27.2) \times \cfrac{ Z^{2} }{n^{2} } \quad eV \end{aligned}\]
Give Bohr's formula for finding the total energy of electron in the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} E_{n} =U_{n}+K_{n} &=-\left( \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} }\right)^{2} \cfrac{2 \pi^{2} m e^{4} Z}{n^{2} h^{2} } \\ \\ &= (- 13.6) \times \cfrac{ Z^{2} }{n^{2} } \quad eV \end{aligned}\] here we can infer,
\(E_{n} = - K_{n} = \cfrac{U_{n}}{2}\)
Give Bohr's formula for finding the frequency of electron in the \(n^{\text {th} }\) orbit.

\[\begin{aligned} \nu_{n} &=\left( \cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} }\right)^{2} \cdot  \cfrac{4 \pi^{2} Z^{2} e^{4} m}{n^{3} h^{3} } \\ &=(6.62 \times 10^{15}) \times \cfrac{ Z^{2} }{n^{3} } \end{aligned}\]
Give the formula for finding the wavelength of radiation in the transition from \(n_{2}\) to \(n_{1}\).

\[ \cfrac{1}{\lambda}=R Z^{2}\left[ \cfrac{1}{n_{1}^{2} }- \cfrac{1}{n_{2}^{2} }\right]\]
where
Rydberg's constant \((R)\) \(=1.097 \times 10^{7} \quad m ^{-1}\)
Smaller the impact parameter, {{c1::larger}} is the angle of scattering (\(\theta\)).
What is a spectral line?

• When the electron in a \(\ce{H}\)-atom jumps from higher energy level to lower energy level, the difference of energies of the two energy levels is emitted as radiation of particular wavelength, known as spectral line.
  • Spectral lines of different wavelengths are obtained for transition of electron between two different energy levels, which are found to fall in a number of spectral series given by:
    • Lyman series
    • Balmer series
    • Paschen series
    • Brackett series
    • Pfund series
Give the formula for determining the value of impact parameter.

\[b=\cfrac{Z e^{2} \cdot \cot \left(\cfrac{\theta}{2}\right)}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} K}\] where
\(b\) = impact parameter
\(Z\) = atomic number of the nucleus
\(\theta\) = scattering angle of \(\alpha\)-particle
\(K\) = kinetic energy of \(\alpha\) -particle
Give the formula for determining distance of closest approach.
\[r_{0}=\cfrac{2 Z e^{2} }{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} K}\]
Give a short note on the composition of the nucleus.

• The nucleus of an atom contains protons and neutrons which are collectively known as nucleons.
  • The number of protons in a nucleus is called its atomic number and is denoted by \(Z\).
  • The total number of protons and neutrons in a nucleus is called its mass number and is denoted by \(A\).
What is a nuclide?

It is a specific nucleus of an atom which is characterised by its atomic number \(Z\) and mass number \(A\). It is represented by \({ }_{Z} X^{A}\) where \(X\) is thแบป chemical symbol of the element.
Give the formula for determining nuclear radius.

\[R=R_{0} A^{1 / 3}\] where
\(R\) = nuclear radius
\(R_{0}\) = constant
\(A\) = mass number
SI unit is fermi. \(1\) \(fm\) \(=\) \(10^{-15}\) \(m\)
Give the formula for determining nuclear density.

\[\rho=\cfrac{\text { mass of nucleus } }{\text { volume of nucleus } }\] where
\(\rho\) = nuclear density
Nuclear density is independent of mass number (\(A\)) and is in order of the \(10^{17} \space kg \space m ^{-3}\).
What are isotopes? Give example(s).

Isotopes of an element are the atoms of the element which have the same atomic number but different mass numbers.
e.g. : \({ }_{1} H ^{1},{ }_{1} H ^{2},{ }_{1} H ^{3}\), are the three isotopes of Hydrogen
List three isotopes of Hydrogen.
\({ }_{1} H ^{1},{ }_{1} H ^{2},{ }_{1} H ^{3}\), are the three isotopes of Hydrogen.
What are isobars? Give example(s).

Isobars are the atoms of different elements which have the same mass number but different atomic numbers.
e.g. : \({ }_{11} Na ^{22}\) and \({ }_{10} Ne ^{22}\)
What are isotones? Give example(s).

Isotones are the nuclides which contain the same number of neutrons.
e.g. \({ }_{17} Cl^{37}\) and \({ }_{19} K ^{39}\)
Write a short note about nuclear forces.

Nuclear forces are the strong forces of attraction which hold together the nucleons (neutrons and protons) in the tiny nucleus of an atom, inspite of strong electrostatic forces of repulsion between protons.

  • Nuclear forces are strongest forces in nature.
  • Nuclear forces are short range forces.
  • Nuclear forces do not obey inverse square law.
  • Nuclear forces arc charge independent.
Do nuclear forces obey inverse square law?
Nuclear forces do not obey inverse square law.
What is mass defect?

The difference in mass of a nucleus and its constituents is known as mass defect.
\[\Delta m=Z m_{p}+(A-Z) m_{n}-m_{N}\] where
\(m_{p}\) = mass of the proton
\(m_{n}\) = mass of the neutron
\(m_{N}\) = mass of the nucleus
Give the formula for determining the binding energy of nucleus.

\[\begin{aligned} E_{b} &=\Delta m c^{2} \\ &=\left[Z m_{p}+(A-Z) m_{n}-m_{N}\right] \times c^{2} \\ & \equiv\left[Z m_{p}+(A-Z) m_{n}-m_{N}\right] \times 931.49 \quad MeV \space u^{-1}\end{aligned}\] where
\(E_b\) = binding energy of nucleus
How do we generally represent a nuclear reaction?

A nuclear reaction is represented by \[A+a \rightarrow B+b+Q\] where
\(A\) = target nucleus
\(a\) = impinging particle
\(B\) and \(b\) = products
\(Q\) = energy released in the process
The nuclear reaction is represented by notation \(A(a, b) B\).
Give the formula for determining the \(Q\) value of a nuclear reaction. What does the sign of the value of \(Q\) signify?

\[Q=\left(m_{A}+m_{a}-m_{B}-m_{b}\right) c^{2}\]

  • If \(Q\) is positive, the reaction is exothermic.
  • If \(Q\) is negative the reaction is endothermic.
List the conservation laws obeyed by nuclear reactions.

Conservation laws obeyed by every nuclear reaction are

  • Conservation of charge number
  • Conservation of mass number
  • Conservation of linear momentum
  • Conservation of energy
What is nuclear fission? Give example(s).

Nuclear fission is the phenomenon of splitting a heavy nucleus into two or more smaller nuclei.

  • e.g. : The nuclear fission of \({ }_{92} U ^{235}\) is represented as \[{ }_{92} U ^{235}+{ }_{0} n^{1} \rightarrow{ }_{56} Ba ^{141}+{ }_{36} Kr ^{92}+ 3 \space{ }_{0} n^{1}+ Q\] The value of \(Q\) is \(200 \space MeV\) per fission reaction.
What is a nuclear chain reaction?

In the nuclear fission of \({ }_{92} U ^{235}\), \[{ }_{92} U ^{235}+{ }_{0} n^{1} \rightarrow{ }_{56} Ba ^{141}+{ }_{36} Kr ^{92}+ 3 \space{ }_{0} n^{1}+ Q\] Under suitable conditions, the three secondary neutrons may cause further fission of \(U^{235}\) nuclei and starts what is known as nuclear chain reaction.
What is a nuclear reactor?

A nuclear reactor uses nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. It is based on the phenomenon of controlled nuclear chain reaction.

  • Moderators like heavy water, graphite, paraffin and Deuterium slow down neutrons.
  • Rods of cadmium and boron serve as control rods.
  • Ordinary water and heavy water serve as coolants.
What is nuclear fusion? Give example(s).

Nuclear fusion is the phenomenon of fusing two or more lighter nuclei to form a single heavy nucleus.

  • e.g. : The nuclear fusion reaction of two deutrons is represented as \[{ }_{1} H ^{2}+{ }_{1} H ^{2} \rightarrow{ }_{2} He ^{4}+24 \space MeV\]
  • Temperature \(\approx 10^{7} K\) is required for fusion to take place.
  • Nuclear fusion is a basis of hydrogen bomb.
The number of protons in a nucleus is called its {{c1::atomic}} number.
Atomic number is denoted by {{c1::\(Z\)}}.
The total number of protons and neutrons in a nucleus is called its {{c1::mass}} number.
Mass number is denoted by {{c1::\(A\)}}
Number of protons in an atom can be represented by {{c1::\(Z\)}}
Number of electrons in an atom can be represented by {{c1::\(Z\)}}
Number of nucleons in an atom can be represented by {{c1::\(A\)}}
Number of neutrons in an atom can be represented by {{c1::\(A-Z\)}}
Nuclear density is {{c1::independent}} of mass number and is in order of the {{c2::\(10^{17}\)}} \(kg \space m ^{-3}\).
If the \(Q\) of a nuclear reaction is positive, the reaction is {{c1::exothermic}}.
If the \(Q\) of a nuclear reaction is negative the reaction is {{c1::endothermic}}.
{{c1::Uncontrolled}} nuclear chain reaction is the basis of an atom bomb.
{{c1::Controlled}} nuclear chain reaction is the basis of a nuclear reactor.
In a nuclear reaction, moderators like {{c1::heavy water, graphite, paraffin and Deuterium}} slow down {{c2::neutrons}}.
In a nuclear reaction, rods of {{c1::Cadmium and Boron}} serve as {{c2::control rods}}.
In a nuclear reaction, {{c1::ordinary water and heavy water}} serve as {{c2::coolants}}.
A temperature of {{c1::\(\approx 10^{7}\)}} \(K\) is required for fusion to take place.
The process of nuclear {{c1::fusion}} is a basis of hydrogen bomb.
What is a nuclear chain reaction controlled by?

Nuclear chain reaction is controlled by Neutron reproduction factor (\(K\))
\[K =\cfrac{\text { rate of production of neutrons } }{\text { rate of loss of neutrons } }\]
The value of \(Q\) in nuclear {{c1::fission}} is {{c2::\(200\)}} \(MeV\) per fission reaction.
List the energy bands of solids.

in ascending order of energy,

  • Valence band
  • Forbidden energy gap (or) forbidden band
  • Conduction band
Brief note on valence band

• Contains valence electrons
  • May be partially or completely filled with electrons
  • Is never empty
  • Electrons in this band don't contribute to electric current
Brief note on conduction band

• Electrons rarely present
  • Either empty or partially filled
  • Electrons in this band are called free electrons
  • Free electrons contribute to the electric current
What are free electrons?

• present in the conduction band of solids
  • contribute to electric current
Brief note on forbidden energy gap (or) forbidden energy band

• energy gap between valence and conduction band
  • no electrons present here
  • it is a measure of energy band gap
What is energy band gap?

• it is the energy required for shifting electrons from valence band to conduction band
  • \[E_{g}=h \nu =\frac{h c}{\lambda}\] \(\lambda\) - wavelength of radiation used in shifting the electron from valence band to conduction band
    \(h\) - Planck's constant
    \(c\) - speed of light
  • value of \(E_{g}\) depends on temperature
What is fermi energy?
The maximum possible energy possessed by free electrons of a material at absolute zero temperature (\(0 K\))
Band theory of metals

• Either the conduction band is partially filled (or) conduction band and valence band partially overlap each other
  • No forbidden energy gap between the valence and conduction bands
Band theory of insulators

• valence band completely filled, conduction band empty
  • very wide forbidden energy gap between valence and conduction band (\(E_g > 5 eV\))
Band theory of semiconductors

• valence band completely filled, conduction band empty
  • small forbidden energy gap between the valence and the conduction bands,of the order \(1 eV\)
  • at absolute zero, semiconductors behave as a perfect insulator
What is a hole?

• is a seat of positive charge produced when an electron breaks away from covalent bond in a semiconductor
  • has a positive charge equal to that of electron
  • mobility of hole is smaller than that of electron
What is an intrinsic semiconductor?

• is a pure semiconductor free from every impurity
  • \[n_{e}=n_{h}=n_{i}\] \(n_{e}\) - number density of electrons in conduction band
    \(n_{h}\) -number density of holes in valence band
    \(n_{i}\) - intrinsic carrier concentration
  • examples are Germanium, Silicon
What happens when electric field is applied across an intrinsic semiconductor?

• electrons and holes move in opposite directions so that
  • total current through the pure semiconductor is given by \[ I=I_{e}+I_{h}\] \(I_{e}\) - free electron current
    \(I_{h}\) - hole current
Effect of temperature on conductivity of intrinsic semiconductors

• intrinsic semiconductor will behave as a perfect insulator at absolute zero
  • with increasing temperature, density of hole-electron pairs increases, and as a result conductivity increases \[ \rho \propto \cfrac{1}{T}\]
  • semiconductors have negative temperature coefficient of resistance
What is doping?

• process of deliberate addition of a desirable impurity to a pure semiconductor in order to increase it's conductivity
  • the impurity atoms added are known as dopants
What is an extrinsic semiconductor?

• it is a doped semiconductor
  • they are of two types :
    • n-type semiconductor
    • p-type semiconductor
Short note on n-type semiconductors

• made when a pure tetravalent semiconductor (like Si or Ge) is doped with a group \(V\) pentavalent impurity like \(\ce{P, As, Sb}\)
  • the pentavalent impurity atoms are known as donor atoms
  • is called "n-type" because the conduction of electricity in such a semiconductor is due to motion of electrons (negative charges)
  • it's called "donor type" semiconductor because the doped impurity atom donates one free electron to semiconductor for conduction
  • electrons are majority carriers and holes are minority carriers
  • it is neutral
  • in \(n\) -type semiconductor \[n_{e} \approx N_{d}>>n_{h}\] \(N_{d}\) - density of donor atoms.
Short note on p-type semiconductors

• made when a pure semiconductor of Si or Ge (tetravalent) is doped with a group \(III\) trivalent impurities like \(\ce{B, Al, In}\)
  • the trivalent impurity atoms are known as acceptor atoms
  • is called "p-type" because the conduction of electricity in such a semiconductor is due to motion of holes (positive charges)
  • is called "acceptor type" semiconductor because the doped impurity atom creates a hole in semiconductor with accepts the electron, which results in conduction
  • holes are majority carries and electrons are minority carriers
  • in \(p\) -type semiconductor \[n_{h} \approx N_{a}>>n_{e}\] \(N_{a}\) - density of acceptor atoms.
The minimum energy required for shifting electrons from valence band to conduction band is known as {{c1::energy band gap}}.
The maximum possible energy possessed by free electrons of a material at absolute zero temperature is called {{c1::fermi energy}}.
Semiconductors have {{c1::negative}} temperature coefficient of resistance.
Why does the conductivity of semiconductors increase with increase in temperature?
it's because the density of hole-electron pairs increases with increase in temperature, and as a result conductivity increases.
The value of energy band gap (\(E_g\)) depends on {{c1::temperature}}.
State Mass Action Law.

"Under thermal equilibrium, the product of the free negative and positive concentrations is a constant independent of the amount of donor and acceptor impurity doping."
\[n_{e} n_{h}=n_{i}^{2}\] where
\(n_{e}\) = number density of electrons
\(n_{h}\) = number density of holes
\(n_{i}\) = intrinsic carrier concentration
Give the general formula for determining the electrical conductivity in any semiconductor.

\[\sigma=e\left(n_{e} \mu_{e}+n_{h} \mu_{h}\right)\] where
\(\mu_{e}\) = electron mobility
\(\mu_{h}\) = hole mobility
\(n_{e}\) = electron density
\(n_{h}\) = hole density
\(e\) = electronic charge
Give a short note on \(p-n\) junction.

• when donor impurities are introduced into one side and acceptors into the other side of a single crystal of an intrinsic semiconductor, a \(p-n\) junction is formed
  • also known as junction diode
  • conducts current in one direction only; offers very high resistance in the reverse direction
  • symbolically represented by
What is depletion region?

• it is the area in the vicinity of the junction containing the uncompensated acceptor and donor ions
  • there's a depletion of mobile charges (holes and free electrons) in this region
  • also known as "space charge region" since this region has immobile ions which are electrically charged
What is a barrier in a \(p-n\) junction?

• The electric field between the acceptor and the donor ions in a \(p-n\) junction is known as barrier.
  • External energy must be applied to get the electrons to move across this barrier.
Define barrier width.
the physical distance from one side of the barrier to the other in a \(p-n\) junction is known as barrier width
What is the height of the barrier in a \(p-n\) junction?
the difference of potential from one side of the barrier in \(p-n\) junction to the other side is known as the height of the barrier.
What factors does the width of the depletion layer and magnitude of potential barrier depend upon?

• nature of material of semiconductor
  • concentration of impurity atoms
For a {{c1::Silicon}} \(p-n\) junction, the barrier potential is about {{c2::\(0.7 V\)}}.
For a {{c1::Germanium}} \(p-n\) junction, the barrier potential is about {{c2::\(0.3 V\)}}.
The thickness of depletion region is of the order of {{c1::\(10^{-6} m\)}} in a \(p-n\) junction.
What is forward biasing of a \(p-n\) junction?

• when positive terminal of external battery is connected to p-side and negative to n-side of \(p-n\) junction, then it is said to be forward biased
  • width of depletion region and barrier height both decrease
  • resistance of the \(p-n\) junction becomes low
What is reverse biasing of a \(p-n\) junction?

• when negative terminal of external battery is connected to p-side and positive to n-side of \(p-n\) junction, then it is said to be reverse biased
    • a very small current flows through \(p-n\) junction when it's reverse biased
    • flow of current is due to movement of minority charge carriers
    • the reverse current is almost independant of applied voltage
  • width of depletion region and barrier height both increase
  • resistance of the \(p-n\) junction becomes high
What is breakdown voltage?
If the reverse bias voltage is continuously increased, then for a certain reverse voltage, the current through the \(p-n\) junction will increase abruptly. This is called breakdown voltage.
Plot the \(I-V\) graph of a \(p-n\) junction.

• \(I-V\) characteristics of a \(p-n\) junction do not obey Ohm's Law
  • \(p-n\) junction graph
Define knee voltage.

• in forward biasing, the voltage at which the current starts to increase rapidly is known as cut-in or knee voltage.
  • for Germanium, it is \(0.3 V\) and for Silicon it is \(0.7V\)
Define dynamic resistance
The ratio of a small change in voltage applied across the \(p-n\) junction to a small change in current through the junction. \[r_{d}=\frac{\Delta V}{\Delta I}\]
Define an ideal diode

• it is a diode which acts as a perfect conductor (with zero voltage across it) when it's forward biased, and as a perfect insulator (with no current flowing through it) when it's reverse biased
  • an ideal diode acts like an automatic switch
    • in forward bias, it acts as a closed switch whereas in reverse bias it acts as an open switch as shown in the figure
\(I-V\) characteristics of an ideal diode
What is a rectifier?

• it is a device which converts AC voltage to DC voltage
  • diode is used an a rectifier
    • it works on the principle that a forward bias \(p-n\) junction conducts and a reverse bias \(p-n\) junction does not conduct
  • they are of two types :
    • half-wave rectifier
    • full-wave rectifier
Describe the working of a half wave rectifier

• diode conducts corresponding to positive half cycle and does not conduct during negative half cycle
  • hence, AC is converted by diode into unidirectional pulsating DC
    • this action is known as half-wave rectification
  • Circuit diagram
  • Wave diagram
Describe the working of a full wave rectifier

• the diodes conduct corresponding both half-cycles alternatively
  • AC is converted by the diodes into unidirectional continuous DC
    • this action is known as full rectification
  • Circuit diagram
  • Wave diagram
What is ripple factor?

Ripple factor is a measure of purity of the DC output of a rectifier. \[
r=\frac{r m s \text { value of the components of wave }}{\text { average or dc value }}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{I_{ rms }}{I_{ dc }}\right)^{2}-1}\]
List some examples of special purpose \(p-n\) junction diodes

• Light emitting diodes (LED)
  • Photodiodes
  • Solar cells
Short note on LEDs

• converts electrical energy into light energy
  • is a heavily doped \(p-n\) junction which operates under forward bias and emits spontaneous radiation
  • \(I-V\) characteristics are similar to that of \(\ce{Si}\) junction diode, but threshold voltages are much higher and slightly different for each colour
  • reverse breakdown voltage very low, around \(5 V\)
  • semiconductor used for fabrication of visible LEDs must at least have a band gap of \(1.8 eV\)
  • the compound semiconductor Gallium Arsenide Phosphide (\(\ce{GaAsP}\)) is used for making LEDs of different colours.
  • \(\ce{GaAs}\) is used for making infrared LED
  • symbol
Short note on photodiodes

• is a special type \(p-n\) junction diode fabricated with a transparent window to allow light to fall on the diode
  • is operated under reverse bias
  • when it is illuminated with light of photon energy greater than the energy gap of the semiconductor, electron-hole pairs are generated in near-depletion region
  • symbol
Short note on solar cells

• converts solar energy into electrical energy
  • is basically a \(p-n\) junction which generates emf when solar radiation falls on the \(p-n\) junction
  • works on the same principle (photovoltaic effect) as the photodiode, except that no external bias is applied and the junction area is kept large
When a \(p-n\) junction is in reverse bias, the flow of current in it is due to the movement of {{c1::minority charge carriers}}.
When a \(p-n\) junction is in reverse bias, the reverse current is {{c1::almost independent}} of applied voltage.
Semiconductor used for fabrication of visible LEDs must at least have a band gap of {{c1::\(1.8 eV\)}}.
{{c1::Gallium Arsenide Phosphide (\(\ce{GaAsP}\))}} is used for making LEDs of different colours.
{{c1::Gallium Arsenide (\(\ce{GaAs}\))}} is used for making infrared LED.
Solar cells and photodiodes work on the principle of {{c1::Photovoltaic effect}}.
{{c1::\(p-n\) junction}} is also known as {{c2::junction diode}}.
The cut in voltage of Silicon is {{c1::\(0.7V\)}}.
The cut in voltage of Germanium is {{c1::\(0.3V\)}}.
What is the working principle of a rectifier?
it works on the principle that a forward bias \(p-n\) junction conducts and a reverse bias \(p-n\) junction does not conduct
Give the formula for determining the electrical conductivity in an intrinsic semiconductor.

\[\sigma_{i}=n_{i} e\left(\mu_{e}+\mu_{h}\right)\] where
\(\mu_{e}\) = electron mobility
\(\mu_{h}\) = hole mobility
\(n_{e}\) = electron density
\(n_{h}\) = hole density
\(e\) = electronic charge
Give the formula for determining the electrical conductivity in an \(n\) -type semiconductor.

\[\sigma_{n}=e N_{d} \mu_{e}\] where
\(\mu_{e}\) = electron mobility
\(\mu_{h}\) = hole mobility
\(n_{e}\) = electron density
\(n_{h}\) = hole density
\(e\) = electronic charge
Give the formula for determining the electrical conductivity in a \(p\) -type semiconductor.

\[\sigma_{p}=e N_{a} \mu_{h}\] where
\(\mu_{e}\) = electron mobility
\(\mu_{h}\) = hole mobility
\(n_{e}\) = electron density
\(n_{h}\) = hole density
\(e\) = electronic charge
The value of Planck's Constant (\(h\)) is {{c1::\(6.626 \times 10^{-34} J \space s\)}}.
The value of Rydberg's Constant (\(R\)) is  {{c1::\(1.097 \times 10^{7} \space m^{-1}\)}}.
The charge of an electron is {{c1::\(-1.6 \times 10^{-19}\)}} \(C\).
The charge of a proton is {{c1::\(+1.6 \times 10^{-19}\)}} \(C\).
The mass of an electron is {{c1::\(9.1 \times 10^{-31}\)}} \(kg\).
The mass of a proton is {{c1::\(1.7 \times 10^{-27}\)}} \(kg\).
The mass of a neutron is {{c1::\(1.7 \times 10^{-27}\)}} \(kg\).
Value of universal gravitational constant (\(G\)) \(=\) {{c1::\(6.67 \times 10^{-11} \quad N \space m^2 \space {kg}^{-2}\)}}
Simplify \(\cfrac{1}{(r-a)^2} - \cfrac{1}{(r+a)^2}\)
\[\left[ \cfrac{1}{(r-a)^2} - \cfrac{1}{(r+a)^2} \right] = \cfrac{4ar}{(r^2-a^2)^2}\]

children.name: 1.1. Physics

fields: List the properties of crystalline solids

• ordered arrangement of particles
  • long range order
  • anisotropic (physical properties have different values in different directions)
  • sharp melting point
List the properties of amorphous solids

• irregular arrangement of particles
  • short range order
  • isotropic (physical properties have same values in different directions)
  • melt over a range of temperature
List the properties of ionic solids.

• held together by ionic bonds
  • constituent particles are ions
  • hard and brittle
  • insulators
  • high melting point
List the properties of metallic solids.

• held together by metallic bonds
  • constituent particles are metal ions and sea of electrons
  • hard, malleable and ductile
  • conductors
  • fairly high melting point
List the properties of covalent solids.

• held together by covalent bonds
  • constituent particles are non-metal atoms
  • hard
  • insulators (except Graphite)
  • very high melting point
List the properties of molecular solids.

• held together by weak van der Waals' forces or hydrogen bonds
  • constituent particles are atoms or molecules
  • soft
  • insulators
  • low melting point
Give a few examples of ionic solids.

• \(\ce{NaCl}\)
  • \(\ce{ZnS}\)
  • \(\ce{CaF2}\)
  • \(\ce{MgO}\)
Give a few examples of metallic solids.

• \(\ce{Fe}\)
  • \(\ce{Cu}\)
  • \(\ce{Ag}\)
  • \(\ce{Na}\)
  • \(\ce{Mg}\)
Give a few examples of covalent solids.

• Diamond
  • Graphite
  • Quartz
  • Carborundum
  • \(\ce{AlN}\)
Give a few examples of molecular solids.

• Ice
  • \(\ce{I2}\)
  • \(\ce{P4}\)
  • \(\ce{S8}\)
  • Naphthalene
  • Camphor
  • Solid \(\ce{CO2}\) (dry ice)
What is a crystal lattice?
The regular three dimensional arrangement of constituent particles in a crystal is called crystal lattice.
What are lattice points?
Constituent particles (atoms, molecules or ions) of a solid crystal are represented as points which are known as lattice points or lattice sites.
What is a unit cell?

• the smallest repeating pattern which represents arrangement of lattice points in a crystal lattice is called a unit cell.
  • a unit cell has characteristic dimensions along the three edges \(a, b\) and \(c\) and interfacial angles \(\alpha\) (between \(b\) and \(c), \beta\) (between \(a\) and \(c)\) and \(\gamma\) (between \(a\) and \(b\) ).
On the basis of primitives or axial distances and interfacial angles there are {{c1::seven}} crystal systems and {{c2::fourteen}} Bravais lattices.
Stacking order of Simple Cubic Packing (\(scp\)) solids.
AAAโฆ type
Stacking order of Hexagonal Close Packed (\(hcp\)) solids.
ABABABโฆ type

What are void spaces?

• in a unit cell, some empty space exists between spheres
  • called void space or hole
  • also called interstitial void, or interstices
  • are of two types :
    • tetrahedral voids
    • octahedral voids
Describe tetrahedral voids.
A void surround by four atoms whose centres when joined form a tetrahedron is called a tetrahedral void.
Describe octahedral voids.
A void surrounded by six atoms whose centres when joined form an octahedron is called an octahedral void.
What are radius ratio rules?

For the stability of an ionic compound, each cation should be surrounded by maximum number of anions and vice-versa for maximum electrostatic forces of attraction. \[\text{Radius ratio}=\cfrac{\text { Radius of the cation }\left(r_{+}\right)}{\text {Radius of the anion }\left(r_{-}\right)}\]
Number of particles \((Z)\) in {{c1::Simple Cubic Packing (\(scp\))}} unit cell : {{c2::\(8 \times \cfrac{1}{8}=1\)}}
Number of particles \((Z)\) in {{c1::Body Centered Cubic (\(bcc\))}} unit cell : {{c2::\(8 \times \cfrac{1}{8}+1=2\)}}
Number of particles \((Z)\) {{c1::Hexagonal Close Packed (\(hcp\))}} unit cell : {{c2::\(12 \times \cfrac{1}{6}+2 \times \cfrac{1}{2}+3=6\)}}
{{c1::Face Centered Cubic (\(fcc\))}} lattice is also known as {{c2::Cubic Close Packed (\(ccp\))}} lattice.
Relation between \(a\), \(d\) and \(r\) in {{c1::Simple Cubic Packing (\(scp\))}} solids : {{c2::\(a=d=2 r\)}}
Relation between \(a\), \(d\) and \(r\) in {{c1::Hexagonal Close Packed (\(hcp\))}} solids : {{c2::\(a=2 r\) and \(h=2 \times \sqrt{\cfrac{2}{3} } \space a\)}}
Relation between \(a\), \(d\) and \(r\) in {{c1::Body Centered Cubic (\(bcc\))}} solids : {{c2::\(\cfrac{\sqrt{3} a}{2}=d=2 r\)}}
If \(N\) is the number of close packed spheres (or number of particles), then the number of {{c1::octahedral}} voids generated \(=\) {{c2::\(N\)}}
If \(N\) is the number of close packed spheres (or number of particles), then the number of {{c1::tetrahedral}} voids generated \(=\) {{c2::\(2 N\)}}

Radius \((r)\) of of {{c1::octahedral}} void \(=\) {{c2::\(0.414 R\)
(where \(R\) is the radius of the spheres in close packing)}}
Formula for calculations involving cell dimensions in a solid crystal.

\[\rho=\cfrac{Z \times M}{a^{3} \times N_{A} \times 10^{-30} } \space g \space cm ^{-3}\] โฆwhere,
\(Z=\) no. of atoms per unit cell
\(a=\) edge length in \(pm\)
\(\rho=\) density of solid
\(M=\) molar mass
\(N_{A}=\) Avogadro's no.
Why do some glass objects recovered from ancient monuments look milky instead of being transparent?
Because they undergo heating during the day, and cooling at night - they anneal over the years, which turns them milky.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Silicon Carbide is a {{c1::covalent or network}} solid.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Argon is a {{c1::non-polar molecular}} solid.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Benzene is a {{c1::non-polar molecular}} solid.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Silver is a {{c1::metallic}} solid.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Sodium Sulphate is a {{c1::crystalline}} solid.
Based on the nature of intermolecular forces, Hydrogen is a {{c1::non-polar molecular}} solid.
When particles are present not only at corners but also at the centre of each face of the unit cell, it's called {{c1::face centered}} unit cell.
What are point defects?

• arises from deviations from ideal arrangement around a point or an atom
  • are of 3 types :
    • stoichiometric defects
    • impurity defects
    • non-stoichiometric defects
What are line defects?
• defects caused by deviations from ideal arrangement in entire row of lattice points
What are stoichiometric defects?

• defects which do not disturb stoichiometry of solid
  • are of 4 types :
    • vacancy defect
    • interstitial defect
    • Frenkel defect
    • Schottky defect
What is vacancy defect?

• arises when lattice sites are vacant
  • decreases density
  • shown by non-ionic solids
What is interstitial defect?

• arises when constituent particles occupy interstitial site
  • increases density
  • shown by non-ionic solids
What is Frenkel defect?

• shown by ionic solid compounds having large difference in the size of cations and anions
  • arises when smaller ion (usually cation) dislocates from it's normal site to an interstitial site
  • does not change density
Give examples of 4 compounds which show Frenkel defect.

• \(\ce{ZnS}\)
  • \(\ce{AgCl}\)
  • \(\ce{AgBr}\)
  • \(\ce{AgI}\)
What is Schottky defect?

• shown by highly ionic solid compounds having small difference in the size of cations and anions
  • arises when equal number of cations and anions are missing
  • decreases density
Give examples of 4 compounds which show Schottky defect.

• \(\ce{NaCl}\)
  • \(\ce{KCl}\)
  • \(\ce{CsCl}\)
  • \(\ce{AgBr}\)
What are impurity defects?
Impurity defects arise when foreign atoms are present at lattice site.
Give examples of compounds which show impurity defect.

• \(\ce{SrCl2}\)
  • \(\ce{CdCl2}\)
  • \(\ce{AgCl}\)
What are non-stoichiometric defects?

• defects which disturb stoichiometry of solids.
  • they're of 2 types :
    • metal excess defect
    • metal deficiency defect
What are metal excess defects?

Can be of two types :

  • due to anionic vacancies
    • a negative ion is missing from it's lattice site, leaving a hole which is occupied by an electron to maintain electrical neutrality
  • due to the presence of extra cations
    • usually arises when metal oxides are overheated
Give examples of compounds which show metal excess defect.

• due to anionic vacancies
    • \(\ce{LiCl}\)
    • \(\ce{NaCl}\)
  • due to the presence of extra cations
    • \(\ce{ZnO}\)
What are metal deficiency defects?
They arise when metal shows variable valency
Give examples of compounds which show metal deficiency defect.
{{c1::Stoichiometric}} defects are also known as {{c2::intrinsic}} or {{c3::thermodynamic}} defects.
When the ionic compound size of anions is much larger than cations then {{c1::Frenkel}} defect occurs.
\(\ce{ZnS}\) exhibits {{c1::Frenkel}} defect.
\(\ce{AgCl}\) exhibits {{c1::Frenkel}} defect.
\(\ce{AgI}\) exhibits {{c1::Frenkel}} defect.
\(\ce{NaCl}\) exhibits {{c1::Schottky}} defect.
\(\ce{KCl}\) exhibits {{c1::Schottky}} defect.
\(\ce{CsCl}\) exhibits {{c1::Schottky}} defect.
\(\ce{AgBr}\) exhibits {{c1::both Frenkel and Schottky}} defect.

\[\text{Packing efficiency}=\cfrac{Z \times \text { Volume of one atom } }{\text { Volume of cubic unit cell } } \times 100\]

• it has 8 atoms in corner of a cube and one atom in the centre
