Define solute.
The component which is present in lesser amount or whose physical state is changed during the formation of solution is called solute.
Define solvent
The component which is present in larger amount and determines state of the solution is called solvent.
Give a few examples of gaseous solutions.

Solute Solvent Examples
Solid Gas Iodine vapours in air, dust of smoke particles in air
Liquid Gas Water vapours in air (humidity)
Gas Gas Oxygen + Nitrogen
Give a few examples of liquid solutions.

Solute Solvent Examples
Solid Liquid Salt/sugar in water
Liquid Liquid Alcohol in water
Gas Liquid Aerated drinks
Give a few examples of solid solutions.

Solute Solvent Examples
Solid Solid Alloys
Liquid Solid \(\ce{Hg}\) in \(\ce{Ag}\), \(\ce{Hg}\) in \(\ce{Zn}\) (Amalgam)
Gas Solid Solution of hydrogen in palladium
Formula for mass percentage.
\(\left(\cfrac{w}{W}\right) \%=\cfrac{w_{2} }{\left(w_{1}+w_{2}\right)} \times 100\)
Formula for volume percentage.
\(\left(\cfrac{v}{V}\right) \%=\cfrac{V_{2} }{\left(V_{1}+V_{2}\right)} \times 100\)
Formula for mass by volume.
\(\left(\cfrac{w}{V}\right) \%=\cfrac{w_{2} }{V_{\text {solution } }(\text { in } mL )} \times 100\)
Formula for mass fraction.
Formula for strength of solution.
Strength \(\left( g L ^{-1}\right)\) \(= \cfrac{w_{2}(\text { in } g )}{V_{\text {solution } }(\text { in } mL )} \times 1000\)
Formula for parts per million.
Parts per Million (\(ppm\)) \(= \cfrac{w_{2} }{\left(w_{1}+w_{2}\right)} \times 10^{6}\)
Formula for molarity.
\(M\) \(\left( mol \space L ^{-1}\right)\) \(= \cfrac{n_2}{V_{\text {solution } }(\text { in } L )}\)
Formula for molality.
\(m\) \(\left(\right.mol \space \left. kg ^{-1}\right)\)  \(= \cfrac{n_2}{w_{1}(\text {in } kg )}\)
Formula for mole fraction.

In liquid solutions,
\(x_{1}=\cfrac{n_{1} }{n_{1}+n_{2} }\) or \(x_{2}=\cfrac{n_{2} }{n_{1}+n_{2} }\)
(where \(\left(x_{1}+x_{2}=1\right)\))

In case of gases only,
\(y_{1}=\cfrac{p_{1} }{p_{1}+p_{2} }\) or \(y_{2}=\cfrac{p_{2} }{p_{1}+p_{2} }\)
(where \(y_{1}+y_{2}=1\))
Define solubility.
Maximum amount of substance that can be dissolved in a specified amount of solvent at a specified temperate is called it's solubility.
What factors affect solubility of a solid in a liquid?

• Nature of solute and solvent (polar-polar vs non polar-non polar)
  • Temperature (endothermic vs. exothermic)
What is the effect of temperature on solubility of a solid in liquid?
If the dissolution process is endothermic \(\left(\Delta_{ sol } H>0\right),\) the solubility increases with rise in temperature, and vice-versa.
What is the effect of pressure on solubility of a solid in liquid?
Insignificant effect on solubility of solids in liquids. (as these are highly incompressible)
What factors affect solubility of a gas in a liquid?

• Pressure (Henry's Law)
  • Temperature (Le Chatlier's Principle)
State Henry's Law.

"The partial pressure of the gas in vapour phase \((p)\) is proportional to the mole fraction of the gas \((x)\) in the solution"

\[p=K_{ H } x\]
(where, \(K_{ H }\) is the Henry's law constant and is different for different gases at a particular temperature. )
What is the effect of nature of solute and solvent on solubility of a solid in liquid?
Polar solutes dissolve in polar solvents, and non-polar solutes dissolve in non-polar solvents.
What is the effect of pressure on solubility of a gas in liquid?
According to Henry's Law, solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the pressure of that gas above the surface of the solution.
What is the effect of temperature on solubility of a gas in liquid?
According to Le Chatelier's principle, the solubility should decrease with increase of temperature. (as dissolution is an exothermic process)
State Le Chatelier's Principle.

"A change in any of the factors that determine the equilibrium conditions of a system will cause the system to change in such a manner so as to reduce or to counteract the effect of the change."

This is applicable to all physical and chemical equilibria.
State Raoult's Law for a solution of volatile liquids.

"For a solution of volatile liquids, the partial vapour pressure of each component of the solution is directly proportional to its mole fraction present in solution."
\[p_1=p_1^{\circ} x_{1} \text { (OR) }p_2=p_2^{\circ} x_2\]
(where \(p_{1}^{\circ}\) and \(p_{2}^{0}\) are vapour pressures of pure components 1 and 2 respectively, at the same temperature.)
State Dalton's Law of Partial Pressure.

"The total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures exerted by each individual gas in the mixture."
\[P_{\text {total } }=p_{1}+p_{2} +...\]

  • The original equation also can be further expanded as:
    \(P_{\text {total } } =x_{1} p_{1}^{\circ}+x_{2} p_{2}^{\circ}\)
    \(~~~~~ \quad=\left(1-x_{2}\right) p_{1}^{\circ}+x_{2} p_{2}^{\circ}\)
    \(~~~~~~~~~=p_{1}^{\circ}+\left(p_{2}^{\circ}-p_{1}^{\circ}\right)x_{2}\)
  • If \(y_{1}\) and \(y_{2}\) are the mole fractions of the components 1 and 2 respectively in the vapour phase then, \(p_{1}=y_{1} P_{\text {total } }\) and \(p_{2}=y_{2} P_{\text {total } }\)
State Raoult's law for solid-liquid solutions.

"Relative lowering in vapour pressure of a solution containing a non-volatile solute is equal to the mole fraction of the solute."
\[\cfrac{p^{\circ}_{pure \space solvent}-p_{solution} }{p^{\circ}_{pure \space solvent} }=x_{2} \]
(where, \(p^{\circ}=\) vapour pressure of pure solvent, \(p_{solution}=\) vapour pressure of solution, \(x_{2}=\) mole fraction of solute.)
Dissolution is an {{c1::exo}}thermic process.
Recognise type of solution, and list it's properties

• Ideal solution
  • \(A-A\) and \(B-B\) interactions \(\approx\) \(A-B\) interactions
  • \(\Delta H_{\operatorname{mix} }=0\) and \(\Delta V_{\operatorname{mix} }=0\)
Recognise type of solution, and list it's properties

• Non-ideal solution. (Positive deviation from Raoult's Law)
  • \(A-A\) and \(B-B\) interactions \(>>A-B\) interactions
  • \(\Delta H_{ mix }>0\) and \(\Delta V_{ mix }>0\)
Recognise type of solution, and list it's properties

• Non-ideal solution. (Negative deviation from Raoult's Law)
  • \(A-A\) and \(B-B\) interactions \(<<A-B\) interactionss
  • \(\Delta H_{ mix }<0\) and \(\Delta V_{ mix }<0\)
Give a few examples of ideal solutions.

• dilute solutions
  • benzene + toluene
  • \(n\)-hexane + \(n\)-heptane
Give a few examples of non-ideal solutions.

• Non-ideal solutions which show positive deviation from Raoult's Law
    • acetone + ethanol
    • acetone + \(\ce{CS _{2} }\)
    • water + methanol
  • Non-ideal solutions which show negative deviation from Raoult's Law
    • acetone + aniline
    • acetone + chloroform
    • water + nitric acid
What are azeotropes?

The mixture of liquids which boil at constant temperature like a pure liquid, and possess same composition of components in liquid as well as vapour phase are called constant boiling mixtures or azeotropic mixtures.
They're classified into two types : minimum and maximum boiling azeotropes.
What are minimum boiling azeotropes?
They're the azeotropes formed by those liquid pairs which show positive deviations from ideal behaviour.
What are maximum boiling azeotropes?
They're the azeotropes formed by those liquid pairs which show negative deviations from ideal behaviour.
What are colligative properties?
Properties which depend only on the number of solute particles dissolved in a definite amount of the solvent and do not depend on the nature of the solute are called colligative properties.
List a few colligative properties.

• Relative lowering of vapour pressure
  • Elevation in boiling point
  • Depression in freezing point
  • Osmotic pressure
The value of Avogadro's number is {{c1::\(6.022 \times 10^{23}\)}}.
Short note on relative lowering of vapour pressure.

• it is a colligative property
  • when a non-volatile solute is dissolved in a solvent, vapour pressure of the solution is lower than that of the pure solvent which is known as lowering of vapour pressure
    \[\begin{aligned} \cfrac{p^{\circ}_{pure \space solvent}-p_{solution} }{p^{\circ}_{pure \space solvent} }=x_{solute} = x_2 &=\cfrac{n_{2} }{n_{1}+n_{2} } \\ &=\cfrac{n_{2} }{n_{1} } \quad \left( \because \text { for dilute solutions, } n_{2}< < n_{1}\right) \\ &=\cfrac{w_{2} \times M_{1} }{M_{2} \times w_{1} } \\ \end{aligned} \]
Short note on elevation in boiling point.

• the boiling point of a solution containing a non-volatile solute is always higher than the boiling point of the pure solvent
  • this increase in boiling point is termed as elevation in boiling point.
  • \(\Delta T_{b} \propto m \implies \Delta T_{b}=K_{b} m =K_{b}\left(\cfrac{w_{2} \times 1000}{M_{2} \times w_{1}(\text { in } g)}\right)\)
  • \(K_{b}\) is known as boiling point elevation constant, molal elevation constant or ebullioscopic constant, having unit \(K \space kg \space mol ^{-1}\)
Short note on depression in freezing point.

• the freezing point of a solution containing a non-volatile solute is always less than the freezing point of the pure solvent
  • this decrease in freezing point is termed as depression in freezing point.
  • \(\Delta T_{f} \propto m \implies \Delta T_{f}=K_{f} m =K_{f}\left(\cfrac{w_{2} \times 1000}{M_{2} \times w_{1}(\text { in } g)}\right)\)
  • \(K_{f}\) is known as freezing point depression constant, molal depression constant or cryoscopic constant, having unit \(K \space kg \space mol ^{-1}\)
Short note on osmotic pressure.

• The hydrostatic pressure which develops on account of osmosis (OR) the excess pressure that must be applied on the solution to prevent osmosis is called osmotic pressure.
  • \(\pi=C R T=\left(\cfrac{n_{2} }{V}\right) R T\)
What are isotonic solutions?
Two solutions having same osmotic pressure at a given temperature are called isotonic solutions.
What do the terms "hypotonic" and "hypertonic" mean?

• one solution is of lower osmotic pressure, it is called hypotonic with respect to the more concentrated solution
  • the more concentrated solution is said to be hypertonic with respect to the dilute solution
What is reverse osmosis?

• if a pressure higher than the osmotic pressure is applied on the solution, the solvent will flow from the solution into the pure solvent through the semipermeable membrane
  • this process is called reverse osmosis
Give one use of reverse osmosis.
It is used in desalination of sea water.
What type of azeotropic mixture will be formed by a solution of acetone and chloroform? Explain why.

• mixture of chloroform and acetone shows negative deviation from Raoult's law, thus it forms maximum boiling azeotrope
  • this is because chloroform molecule is able to form hydrogen bond with acetone molecule
  • this decreases the escaping tendency of molecules for each component and consequently, the vapour pressure decreases resulting in negative deviation from Rault's Law
Define osmosis.
The movement of solvent molecules from less concentrated solution to more concentrated solution through semipermeable membrane is termed as osmosis.
Relative lowering of vapour pressure is a {{c1::colligative}} property.
{{c1::\(K_{f}\)}} is known as {{c2::freezing point depression}} constant, {{c3::molal depression}} constant, or {{c4::cryoscopic}} constant.
{{c1::\(K_{b}\)}} is known as {{c2::boiling point elevation}} constant, {{c3::molal elevation}} constant, or {{c4::ebullioscopic}} constant
The unit of \(K_{b}\) or \(K_{f}\) is {{c1::\(K \space kg \space mol ^{-1}\)}}.
List the differences between electrochemical cell and electrolytic cell (any 3)

Electrochemical cell Electrolytic cell
device which converts chemical energy into electrical energy device which converts electrical energy into chemical energy
based upon spontaneous redox reaction (\(\Delta G<0\)) based upon non-spontaneous redox reaction (\(\Delta G>0\))
two electrodes are usually set up in separate beakers both the electrodes are suspended in solution in the same beaker
electrolyte in each beaker is different only one electrolyte taken
electrodes are of different materials electrodes may be of same or of different material
electrode on which oxidation takes place = anode (\(-ve\) pole)
electrode on which reduction takes place = cathode (\(+ve\) pole)		 electrode connected to pole on which reduction takes place = cathode (\(-ve\) terminal)
the other electrode = anode (\(+ve\) terminal)
a salt bridge or porous pot is used for setup no salt bridge is used
Give Nernst equation for a reduction reaction.

for the reaction \(M^{n+}_{(a q)}+n e^{-} \longrightarrow M_{(s)}\), \[E_{\text {cell } }=E_{\text {cell } }^{\circ}-\cfrac{2.303 R T}{n F} \log \cfrac{1}{\left[M_{(a q)}^{n+}\right]}\] (where \(R\)=Gas constant, \(F\)= Faraday's constant, \(T\) = Temperature (in \(K\)), \(n\) = number of electrons transferred)

but at \(T = 298 K\), \[E_{\text {cell } }=E_{\text {cell } }^{\circ}-\cfrac{0.0591}{n} \log \cfrac{1}{\left[M_{(a q)}^{n+}\right]}\]
How is EMF of a concentration calculated?
List the applications of Nernst equation.

it can be used :

  • to calculate electrode potential of a cell
  • to calculate equilibrium constant
How to calculate the electrode potential of a cell?

by using Nernst equation, for a cell a \(aA+b B \stackrel{n e^{-} }{\longrightarrow} x X+y Y\), at \(T = 298 K\), \[E_{\text {cell } }=E_{\text {cell } }^{\circ}-\cfrac{0.0591}{n} \log \cfrac{[X]^{x}[Y]^{y} }{[A]^{a}[B]^{b} }\]
How to calculate equilibrium constant of a cell?
at equilibrium, \(E_{\text {cell } }=0\). Therefore, \[ E_{\text {cell } }^{\circ}=\cfrac{0.0591}{n} \log K_{c}\] (where \(T =298 K\))
Relation between cell potential and Gibbs energy change.
\[\Delta G^{\circ}=-n F E_{\text {cell } }^{\circ}\]
Formula and unit for resistance.
\[R = \rho \cfrac{l}{a}\] Unit = Ohm \(\left(\Omega\right)\)
Formula and unit for conductance.
\[G=\cfrac{1}{R}\] Unit = \(\text{Ohm } ^{-1}\left(\Omega^{-1}\right)\) (OR) \(\text{Siemens} \space  (S)\)
Effect of dilution on conductance in an electrolytic solution.
Value of conductance \((G)\) increases, as larger number of ions are produced.
Formula and unit for specific conductance.
\[\kappa=\cfrac{1}{\rho}\] Unit = \(Ohm ^{-1} cm ^{-1}\) (OR) \(S \space m ^{-1}\)
Effect of dilution on specific conductance in an electrolytic solution.
Value of specific conductance \((\kappa)\) decreases, as number of ions per \(cm ^{3}\) decreases.
Formula and unit for conductivity.
\[\kappa =\cfrac{1}{\rho}\] Unit = \(Ohm ^{-1} cm ^{-1}\) (OR) \(S \space m ^{-1}\)
Effect of dilution on conductivity in an electrolytic solution.
Value of conductivity  \(( \kappa)\) decreases, as number of ions per \(cm ^{3}\) decreases.
Formula and unit for equivalent conductivity.
\[\Lambda_{eq} = \kappa V = \kappa \space \cfrac{1000}{N}\] Unit = \(\Omega^{-1} cm ^{2} eq ^{-1}\) (OR) \(S \space m ^{2} eq ^{-1}\)
Effect of dilution on equivalent conductivity in an electrolytic solution.
Value of equivalent conductivity \((\Lambda_{eq})\) increases with dilution, due to large increase in \(V\).
Formula and unit for molar conductivity.
\[\Lambda_{m} = \kappa V = \kappa \space \cfrac{1000}{M}\] Unit = \(\Omega^{-1} cm ^{2} mol ^{-1}\) (OR) \(S \space m ^{2} mol ^{-1}\)
Effect of dilution on molar conductivity in an electrolytic solution.
Value of molar conductivity \((\Lambda_{m})\) increases with dilution, due to large increase in \(V\).
What is limiting molar conductivity?
When concentration approaches zero (that is, at infinite dilution), the molar conductivity is known as limiting molar conductivity (\(\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}\))
How do we measure variation of molar conductivity with concentration? Also plot the graph.

• for a strong electrolyte, it is shown by Debye-Huckel Onsager equation
    \(\Lambda_{m}=\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}-A \sqrt{C}\)
  • plot of \(\Lambda_{m}\) against \(C^{1 / 2}\) is a straight line with intercept equal to \(\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}\) and slope equal to ' \(-A\) '

    thus, \(\Lambda_{m}\) decreases linearly with \(\sqrt{C}\)
Give the formula for Debye-Huckel Onsager equation.

\[\Lambda_{m}=\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}-A \sqrt{C}\] where
\(\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}=\) limiting molar conductivity
\(\Lambda_{m}=\) molar conductivity at \(V\) -dilution
\(A=\) constant which depends upon nature of solvent and temperature
\(C=\) Concentration
Variation of molar conductivity with concentration for weak electrolytes.
• \(\Lambda_{m}\) increases as \(C\) decreases but does not reach a constant value even at infinite dilution. Hence, their \(\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}\) cannot be determined experimentally
Variation of molar conductivity with concentration for strong electrolytes.

• there is only a small increase in conductance with dilution
  • this is because a strong electrolyte is completely dissociated in solution and so, the number of ions remain constant, and on dilution, interionic attractions decreases as ions move far apart.
State Kohlrausch's law.

Kohlrausch's law of independent migration of ions states that limiting molar conductivity of an electrolyte can be represented as the sum of the individual contributions of the anion and cation of the electrolyte. \[\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}=v_{+} \lambda_{+}^{0}+v_{-} \lambda_{-}^{0} \]
{{c1::Electrochemical}} cell is also known as {{c2::Galvanic}} or {{c3::Voltaic}} cell.
The reaction in {{c1::electrochemical}} cell is based upon {{c2::spontaneous redox (\(\Delta G<0\))}} reaction.
The reaction in {{c1::electrolytic}} cell is based upon {{c2::non-spontaneous redox (\(\Delta G>0\))}} reaction.
The electrode on which {{c1::oxidation}} takes pace is called {{c2::anode}}.
The electrode on which {{c1::reduction}} takes pace is called {{c2::cathode}}.
In an electrochemical cell, the {{c1::anode}} is the {{c2::negative}} pole.
In an electrochemical cell, the {{c1::cathode}} is the {{c2::positive}} pole.
In an electrolytic cell, the {{c1::cathode}} is the {{c2::negative}} pole.
In an electrolytic cell, the {{c1::anode}} is the {{c2::positive}} pole.
{{c1::Specific conductance}} is also referred to as {{c2::conductivity}}.
Give a few applications of Kohlrausch's Law.

• calculation of molar conductivity of weak electrolytes
  • calculation of degree of dissociation
  • calculation of dissociation constant (\(K_C\)) of weak electrolyte
How to calculate degree of dissociation using Kohlrausch's Law?

Using Kohlrausch's Law, \[\text { Degree of dissociation }(\alpha)=\cfrac{\Lambda_{m} }{\Lambda_{m}^{\circ} }
=\cfrac{\text { Molar conductivity at concentration } C}{\text { Molar conductivity at infinite dilution } }\]
What is electrolysis?
It is the process of a decomposition of an electrolyte by passing electricity through its aqueous solution or molten state.
Write the reactions involved in the electrolysis of molten \(\ce{NaCl}\).

• electrolyte : molten \(\ce{NaCl}\)
  • reaction at cathode : \(Na _{(l)}^{+}+e^{-} \longrightarrow Na _{(s)}\)
  • reaction at anode : \(Cl^-_{(l)} \longrightarrow \cfrac{1}{2} Cl _{2(g)}+e^{-}\)
Write the reactions involved in the electrolysis of aqueous \(\ce{NaCl}\).

• electrolyte : aqueous \(\ce{NaCl}\)
  • reaction at cathode : \(H _{2} O _{(l)}+e^{-} \longrightarrow \cfrac{1}{2} H _{2(g)}+ OH _{(a q)}^{-}\)
  • reaction at anode : \(Cl _{(a q)}^{-} \longrightarrow \cfrac{1}{2} Cl _{2(g)}+e^{-}\)
Write the reactions involved in the electrolysis of dilute \(\ce{H2SO4}\).

• electrolyte : \(\text{dil. }\ce{H2SO4}\)
  • reaction at cathode : \(H _{(a q)}^{+}+e^{-} \longrightarrow \cfrac{1}{2} H _{2( g )}\)
  • reaction at anode : \(2 H _{2} O _{(l)} \longrightarrow O _{2(g)}+4 H _{(a q)}^{+}+4 e^{-}\)
Write the reactions involved in the electrolysis of concentrated \(\ce{H2SO4}\).

• electrolyte : \(\text{conc. }\ce{H2SO4}\)
  • reaction at cathode : \(H _{(a q)}^{+}+e^{-} \longrightarrow \cfrac{1}{2} H _{2( g )}\)
  • reaction at anode : \(2 {SO _{4} }_{(a q)}^{2-} \longrightarrow {S _{2} O _{8} }_{(a q)}^{2-}+2 e^{-}\)
List a few types of commercial cells with examples.

• Primary cells
    • cells which once exhausted cannot be used again
    • eg : dry cell, mercury cell
  • Secondary cells
    • rechargeable cell which can be used again and again
    • eg : nickel, cadmium cell and lead storage battery.
  • Fuel cells
    • cells which can convert the energy of combustion of fuels such as \(\ce{H _{2} }\), \(\ce{CO}\) or \(\ce{CH _{4} }\) into electrical energy
    • eg : \(\ce{H _{2}- O _{2} }\) fuel cell
How to calculate dissociation constant of weak electrolyte?

Using Kohlrausch's Law, \[\begin{array}{cccc} \space &~~~~~~~~~~A B~~~~~~\rightleftharpoons & ~~~~~~~A^{+}~~~+& B^{-} \\ \text{Initial concentration } & c & 0 & 0 \\ \text{Equilibrium concentration } & (c-\alpha c) & \alpha c & \alpha c \end{array}\] \[K_{c}=\cfrac{\alpha c \times \alpha c}{(c-\alpha c)}=\cfrac{\alpha^{2} c }{(1-\alpha)} \]
How to calculation molar conductivity of weak electrolytes? (say, of \(\ce{CH3COOH}\))
Relation between equilibrium constant and Gibbs energy change.
\[\Delta G^{\circ}=(-2.303) \space R T  \space \log K_{c}\]
What factors does the value of constant \(A\) in Debye-Huckel Onsager equation depend on?

\[\Lambda_{m}=\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}-A \sqrt{C}\] \(A\) depends on:

  • nature of solvent
  • temperature
Value of Farady's constant \((F)\) \(=\) {{c1::\(96485 \space C \space mol^{-1}\)}}
Value of Ideal Gas Constant \((R)\) \(=\) {{c1::\(8.314 \space J \space K^{-1} \space mol^{-1}\)}}
Give the formula for Kohlrausch's law.

\[\Lambda_{m}^{\circ}=v_{+} \lambda_{+}^{0}+v_{-} \lambda_{-}^{0} \] where
\(\lambda_{+}^{0}\) and \(\lambda_{-}^{\circ}\) = the limiting molar conductivities of the cation and anion respectively
\(v_{+}\) and \(v_{-}\) = stoichiometric number of cations and anions respectively in one formula unit of the of electrolyte
Define rate of a reaction.

The rate of a reaction can be defined as the change in concentration of a reactant or a product in unit time.

  • For a reaction \(R \longrightarrow P\), \[\text{Rate} =-\frac{\Delta[R]}{\Delta t} \text{ (OR) }+\frac{\Delta[P]}{\Delta t}\]
  • Units of rate
    • for liquid reactions: \(mol \space L ^{-1} s ^{-1}\)
    • for gaseous reactions: \(atm \space s ^{-1}\)
Define average rate of reaction.
It is the average value of rate of reaction during a large time interval. \[r_{a v}=\frac{-\Delta[R]}{\Delta t}=\frac{+\Delta[P]}{\Delta t}\]
Define instantaneous rate of reaction.

It is the rate of a reaction at a particular instant of time.
That is, when \(\Delta t\) approaches zero, \[r_{inst}=\frac{-d[R]}{d t}=\frac{+d[P]}{d t}\]
List the factors which influence the rate of a reaction.

• concentration
  • physical state of reactants
  • temperature
  • presence of catalyst
  • surface area of reactants
  • presence of light
  • activation energy
What is the effect of concentration on the rate of a reaction?
Greater the concentrations of the reactants, faster is the rate of reaction.
How does physical state of reactants affect the rate of a reaction?
Reactions involving gaseous reactants are faster than reactions containing solid and liquid reactants.
What is the effect of temperature on the rate of a reaction?

The rate of reaction increases with increase of temperature. For most reactions, rate of reaction becomes almost double with \(10^{\circ} C\) rise of temperature. (because the rate constant \((k)\) is nearly doubled)
What is the effect of catalysts on the rate of a reaction?
A catalyst generally increases the speed of a reaction.
What is the effect of surface area of reactants on the rate of a reaction?
For a reaction involving a solid reactant or catalyst - the greater the surface area, the faster is the reaction.
What is the effect of presence of light on the rate of a reaction?
Photochemical reactions take place in the presence of light only.
What is the effect of activation energy on the rate of a reaction?
Lower the activation energy faster is the reaction.
What is rate law?

The equation that correlates the rate of reaction with concentration of reactants is known as rate law.

For a simple reaction \(A+B \rightarrow C+D\), \[\text{Rate} =k[A][B]\] where
\(k =\) rate constant, which is equal to the rate of reaction when concentration of each reactant is unity
List the differences between molecularity and order of a reaction.

Molecularity of a reaction Order of a reaction
it is the total number of species
taking part in a chemical reaction		 is the sum of the powers of the
concentration terms of reacting
species in the rate law equation
it is a theoretical concept it is an experimental quantity
derived from the mechanism of reaction derived from rate expression
can neither be zero nor fractional
- always a whole number		 may be zero, fractional or an
integer (may range from \(0\) to \(3\))
applicable only to elementary reactions
(overall molecularity of a complex
reaction has no significance)		 applicable to elementary as well as
complex reactions
Define half life of reaction.

The time in which the concentration of a reactant is reduced to one half of its initial concentration is called half life of the reaction. \[t_{1 / 2} \propto \frac{1}{a^{n-1}}\] where
\(n\) = order of the reaction
Give rate law for a zero order reaction.
for \(0\) order reaction, \[Rate =k[A]^{0}\]
Give integrated rate law for a zero order reaction.
for \(0\) order reaction, \[[A]_{t}=(-k t)+[A]_{0}\]
Give half life equation for a zero order reaction.
for \(0\) order reaction, \[t_{1 / 2}=\frac{[A]_{0}}{2 k}\]
What is the unit of rate constant in a zero order reaction?

for \(0\) order reaction,
Unit = \(mol \space L ^{-1} s ^{-1}\)
How to plot graph of a zero order reaction?
for \(0\) order reaction, we would plot an \([A] \text{ vs } t\) graph, with slope \(=(-k)\)
Give rate law for a first order reaction.
for \(1st\) order reaction, \[Rate =k[A]^{1}\]
Give integrated rate law for a first order reaction.
for \(1st\) order reaction, \[\ln[A]_{t}=(-k t)+ \ln [A]_{0}\]
Give half life equation for a first order reaction.
for \(1st\) order reaction, \[t_{1 / 2}=\frac{0.693}{k}\]
What is the unit of rate constant in a first order reaction?

for \(1st\) order reaction,
Unit = \(s ^{-1}\)
How to plot graph of a first order reaction?
for \(1st\) order reaction, we would plot an \(ln[A] \text{ vs } t\) graph, with slope \(=(-k)\)
What is a pseudo first order reaction?
Those reactions which are not truly of the first order, but under certain conditions become reactions of the first order are called pseudo first order reactions.
Give some examples of a pseudo first order reaction?

• Acid hydrolysis of ethyl acetate
  • Acid catalysed inversion of cane sugar
Inversion of cane sugar in aqueous solution to glucose and fructose is an example of {{c1::pseudo-first order (slow)}} reaction.
Give full reaction and rate equation for acid hydrolysis of ethyl acetate.

\[\begin{aligned} & CH_{3} COOC_{2} H _{5}+ H_{2} O \stackrel{ H ^{+}}{\longrightarrow} CH_{3} COOH + C_{2} H_{5} OH \\ \\ Rate &=k^{\prime}\left[ CH_{3} COOC_{2} H_{5}\right]\left[ H_{2} O \right] \\ &=k\left[ CH_{3} COOC_{2} H_{5}\right] \end{aligned}\]
(where \(k=k^{\prime}\left[ H_{2} O \right]\))
Give full reaction and rate equation for acid catalysed inversion of cane sugar.
What is the unit of rate for liquid reactions?
\(mol \space L ^{-1} s ^{-1}\)
What is the unit of rate for gaseous reactions?
\(atm \space s ^{-1}\)
Define adsorption.

It is the process of accumulation of molecular species at the surface rather than in the bulk of a solid or liquid.
It is of two types:

  • physisorption (or physical adsorption)
  • chemisorption (or chemical adsorption)
What is adsorbate?
The molecular species or substance, which concentrates or accumulates at the surface.
What is adsorbent?
The material on the surface of which the adsorption takes place.
List the differences between adsorption and absorption.

Adsorption Absorption
is a surface phenomenon, occurs
only at the surface of the adsorbent		 is a bulk phenomenon, occurs
throughout the body of the material
the concentration on the surface of
adsorbent is different from that in the bulk		 the concentration is the same throughout the material
it's rate is high in the beginning and then decreases till equilibrium is attained it's rate remains the same throught the process
What is desorption?
It is the process of removing an adsorbed substance from the surface.
What is sorption?
It is the term used when both absorption and adsorption occur simultaneously.
\(\Delta G\) {{c1::\(<\)}} \(0\) for adsorption.
\(\Delta H\) {{c1::\(<\)}} \(0\) for adsorption.
\(\Delta S\) {{c1::\(<\)}} \(0\) for adsorption.
What is physisorption?
When the particles are held to the surface by physical forces like van der Waals forces, the adsorption is called physical adsorption or physisorption.
What is chemisorption?
When the particles are held to the surface by the chemical forces or by chemical bonds, the adsorption is called chemical adsorption or chemisorption.
List the differences between physisorption and chemisorption. (any 3)

Property Physisorption Chemisorption
Enthalpy Low enthalpy, is in the order of \(20-40 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\) High enthalpy, is in the order of \(80-240 \space kJ mol ^{-1}\)
Reversibility Reversible process Irreversible process
Effect of temperature With increase in temperature, extent of physisorption decreases (because adsorption is a exothermic process and kinetic energy of gas molecules increase with temperature) Chemisorption first increases with temperature upto a certain extent and then decreases. A gas adsorbed at low temperature by physical adsorption may change into chemisorption at high temperature.
Selectivity Not selective in nature (does not depend upon the nature or chemical properties of gas and adsorbent) Highly selective in nature (depends upon the nature of gas and adsorbent)
Nature and state of adsorbate The extent of adsorption depends upon the ease of liquefaction of the gas The state of adsorbed molecules may be different from that in the bulk
Activation energy No appreciable energy needed High activation energy needed
Pressure Increase in pressure increases physisorption Increase in pressure decreases chemisorption
Layers Multimolecular layer Monomolecular layer
List the factors which affect adsorption of gases on solids.

• nature of adsorbent
  • surface area of adsorbent
  • nature of the gas being adsorbed
  • pressure
  • temperature
What is the affect of the nature of adsorbent on the adsorption of gases on solids?

• greater the strained forces on the surface, more is the ease with which adsorption takes place on the surface
  • activated adsorbents have high adsorbing power.
What is the affect of the surface area of adsorbent on the adsorption of gases on solids?
Greater the surface area, more is the adsorption.
What is the affect of the nature of the gas being adsorbed on the adsorption of gases on solids?

Easily liquefiable gases like \(NH _{3}, HCl , Cl _{2}, SO _{2}\),
\(CO _{2}\), etc. (whose critical temperature is high) are adsorbed to greater extent.
What is the affect of pressure on the adsorption of gases on solids?
At constant temperature, adsorption increases with increase in pressure. The effect of pressure is large at low temperature.
What is the affect of temperature on the adsorption of gases on solids?
Since adsorption is an exothermic process, according to Le-Chatelier's principle, adsorption decreases with increase in temperature.
Enthalpy of physisorption is of the order {{c1::\(20-40 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\)}}
Enthalpy of chemisorption is of the order {{c1::\(80-240 \space kJ mol ^{-1}\)}}
With {{c1::increase}} in temperature, extent of physisorption {{c2::decreases}}.
Increase in pressure results in {{c1::increase}} in amount of physisorption.
Increase in pressure results in {{c1::decrease}} in amount of chemisorption.
Physisorption results in a {{c1::multimolecular}} layer.
Chemisorption results in a {{c1::monomolecular}} layer.
Give reason - "With increase in temperature, extent of physisorption decreases".
this is because adsorption is an exothermic process and kinetic energy of gas molecules increase with temperature
What is Freundlich adsorption isotherm for gases?

Freundlich adsorption isotherm is an empirical relationship between the quantity of gas absorbed by unit mass of solid absorbent, and pressure at a particular temperature.

  • for adsorption of gases by a solid adsorbents, ,\[\begin{aligned} \cfrac{x}{m} & =k \cdot p^{\cfrac{1}{n}} \\ \\ \log \cfrac{x}{m} &= \log k + \cfrac{1}{n} \cdot \log p \\ \end{aligned}~~~~~~~~\left( \text{where } 0 \leq \cfrac{1}{n} \leq 1 \right)\] where
    \(m\) = mass of the adsorbent
    \(x\) = mass of the adsorbate
    \(k, n\) = constants which depend on the nature of adsorbent and the gas at particular temperature
    \(p\) = pressure
    \(T\) = temperature
  • for adsorption of solutes from solutions, \[\frac{x}{m}=k \cdot C^{1 / n}\] where
    \(C\) = equilibrium concentration (that is, concentration when adsorption is complete)
How would we plot a graph for Freundlich adsorption isotherm?

• for \(\cfrac{x}{m} =k \cdot p^{\cfrac{1}{n}} \quad\), it is a plot of \(\cfrac{x}{m}\) vs \(p\) at constant \(T\)
  • for \(\log \cfrac{x}{m} = \log k + \cfrac{1}{n} \cdot \log p \quad\), it is a plot of \(\log \cfrac{x}{m}\) vs \(\log p\) at constant \(T\)
    • also for \(\log \cfrac{x}{m} = \log k + \cfrac{1}{n} \cdot \log C \quad\), plot of \(\log \cfrac{x}{m}\) vs \(\log C\) is linear.
In Freundlich adsorption isotherm, what do the constants \(k\) and \(n\) depend on?
They depend on the nature of adsorbent and the nature of gas at a particular temperature.
What are promoters?
Promoters are substances that enhance the activity of a catalyst.
What are poisons?
• substances that decrease the activity of a catalyst
What does activity of a catalyst mean?
It is the capacity of a catalyst to increase the speed of the chemical reaction
What does selectivity of a catalyst mean?
It is the ability of a catalyst to direct a reaction to yield a particular product.
What are colloids?

A colloid is a heterogeneous system in which one substance (dispersed phase) is dispersed as very fine particles in another substance (dispersion medium). The range of diameters of colloidal particles is between \(10^{-9}\) to \(10^{-6} m\).
They're classified as:

  • based on physical state of dispersed phase and dispersion medium
    • sols
    • gels
    • emulsions
  • based on nature of interaction between dispersed phase and dispersion medium
    • lyophilic colloids
    • lyophobic colloids
  • based on type of particles of the dispersed phase
    • multimolecular colloids
    • macromolecular colloids
    • associated colloids
What are sols?
Colloidal solution of solid (dispersed phase) in liquid (dispersion medium).
What are gels?
Colloidal solution of liquid (dispersed phase) in solid (dispersion medium).
What are emulsions?

Colloidal solution of liquid (dispersed phase) in liquid (dispersion medium).
They're of two types:
1) Oil in water type emulsions
2) Water in oil type emulsions
What are lyophilic colloids?

• liquid-loving (dispersed phase and dispersion medium attract each other)
  • directly formed
  • reversible in nature
  • quite stable, cannot be easily coagulated
What are lyophobic colloids?

• liquid-hating (dispersed phase and dispersion medium repel each other)
  • prepared by special methods
  • irreversible in nature
  • not stable, can be readily coagulated; need stabilising agents for their preservation
What are multimolecular colloids?

• formed by aggregation of a large number of atoms or molecules (diameter \(10^{-9} m\))
  • held by weak Van der Waals' forces
What are macromolecular colloids?
• formed by molecules of large size
What are associated colloids?

The substances which at low concentrations behave as strong electrolytes, but at higher concentrations exhibit colloidal behaviour due to the formation of aggregate particles (called micelles) are known as associated colloids.
What are micelles?
Aggregated particles of associated colloids at high concentration are called micelles.
List the properties show by colloidal solutions.

• colligative properties
  • Tyndall effect (optical property)
  • Brownian movement (mechanical property)
  • charge on colloidal particles
  • Electrophoresis (electrical property)
  • coagulation
What are the colligative properties exhibited by colloidal solutions?

• colloids show colligative properties like relative lowering of vapour pressure, elevation of boiling point, etc.
  • magnitude of colligative properties of colloids is much less than true solutions, due to larger size of colloidal particles
What is Tyndall effect?

• When a beam of light is passed through a colloidal solution and viewed perpendicular to the path of incident light, the path of beam is illuminated by a bluish light. This phenomenon is called Tyndall effect.
  • this is due to the fact that colloidal particles scatter light in all directions
  • it is an optical property shown by colloidal solutions
What is Brownian movement?

Brownian movement it is defined as the zig-zag movement of colloidal particles due to the unbalanced bombardment by the molecules of dispersion medium.

  • it is a mechanical property shown by colloidal solutions
  • it has a stirring effect which does not permit the particles to settle and thus, is one of the reasons responsible for the stability of colloidal solutions
What is the nature of charge on colloidal particles?

• colloidal particles always carry an electric charge and nature of charge (\(+ve\) or \(-ve\)) is same on all the particles in a given colloidal solution
    • this equal and same type of charge on colloidal particles causes repulsion between them, preventing coagulation of the sol
  • the charge is due to preferential adsorption of ions from solution.
What is electrophoresis?

The movement of colloidal particles towards one of the electrodes under an applied electric potential is called electrophoresis.

  • it is an electrical property of colloidal solutions
  • the direction depends on the type of charge on colloidal particles
What is coagulation of colloids?
Coagulation is the precipitation of colloidal solution by induced aggregation of colloidal particles.
How can lyophobic sols be coagulated?

They can be coagulated by

  • electrophoresis
  • boiling
  • persistent dialysis
  • mixing of oppositely charged sols
  • addition of electrolytes
What are Hardy-Schulze rules?

• According to Hardy-Schulze rule in case of electrolytes, the ion carrying charge opposite to that of colloidal particles is effective in causing coagulation.
  • Greater the valency of the ion causing coagulation, greater is the coagulating power.
What is coagulating value?

• The minimum concentration of an electrolyte in \(\text{millimoles per litre}\) required to cause precipitation of a sol in two hours is called coagulating value.
  • the smaller the quantity needed, the higher will be the coagulating power of an ion
How can lyophilic sols be coagulated?

They can be coagulated by

  • addition of electrolytes
  • addition of a suitable solvent
In Freundlich adsorption isotherm, when {{c1::\(\cfrac{1}{n}=0\) and \(\cfrac{x}{m}=\text{constant}\)}}, the adsorption varies {{c2::independently}} of pressure.
In Freundlich adsorption isotherm, when {{c1::\(\cfrac{1}{n}=1\) and \(\cfrac{x}{m}=k p\), (that is, when \(\cfrac{x}{m} \propto P\))}}, the adsorption varies {{c2::directly}} with pressure.
{{c1::Hydrated metallic oxides}} are examples of {{c2::positively}} charged sols.
{{c1::Metallic particles}} are examples of {{c2::negatively}} charged sols.
Give two applications of adsorption.

• deionisation of water
  • used in chromatographic analysis
What is the role of activated charcoal in gas mask?
Activated charcoal in gas mask adsorb the poisonous gases present in air and thus purify the air for breathing.
Adsorption of a gas on surface of solid is generally accompanied by a decrease in entropy, still it is called a spontaneous process. Explain why?

For the process to be spontaneous, \(\Delta G\) must be negative. \[\Delta G=\Delta H-T \Delta S\] As \(\Delta S\) (entropy change) is negative, \(\Delta G\) can be negative only if \(\Delta H\) is negative and greater than \(T \Delta S\).
One similarity between physisorption and chemisorption.
Physical adsorption and chemical adsorption both increase with increase in surface area of the adsorbent.
Physisorption is reversible while chemisorption is irreversible. Why?

• physisorption takes place with the help of non-covalent bonding between an adsorbate and an adsorbent; it makes the process reversible.
  • chemisorption, on the other hand, takes place with the help of covalent bonding; it makes the process irreversible.
Why is rate of chemisorption low at lower temperatures?
Rate of adsorption is low at lower temperature because of high energy of activation hence, with increasing temperature rate of adsorption increases initially, but then decreases.
Physisorption is multilayered, while chemisorption is monolayered. Explain why?

• chemisorption forms monomolecular layer because chemical bonds can be formed only with the layer of molecules coming in direct contact with the surface of the adsorbent
  • physisorption forms multimolecular layer because the gas can be adsorbed one over the other by the Van der Waals forces, and thus, multimolecular layers are formed under high pressure
Out of \(\ce{NH_{3}}\) and \(\ce{CO_{2}}\), which gas will be adsorbed more readily on the surface of activated charcoal and why?
\(\ce{NH_{3}}\) gas will be adsorbed more readily on the surface, because it has higher critical temperature than \(\ce{CO_{2}}\) gas.
Between \(\ce{N2}\) and \(\ce{NH3}\) gas, which has higher critical temperature?
\(\ce{NH3}\) gas has a higher critical temperature than \(\ce{N2}\) gas.
What is adsorption isotherm?
It is the variation in the amount of gas adsorbed by the adsorbent with pressure, at a constant temperature.
What does this graph represent?
The graph represent adsorption isotherm - the curves indicate that on increasing temperature, physical adsorption decreases at a fixed pressure.
How do colloidal sols maintain their stability?

• Brownian movement: it has a stirring effect which does not permit the particles to settle
  • Electrostatic stabilisation: equal and same type of charge on the colloidal particles which causes repulsion between them, thus preventing the coagulation of the sol.
The size of particles in a true solution is about {{c1::\(10^{-10} \space m\)}}.
What is Kraft temperature?
The formation of micelles takes place only above a particular temperature called Kraft temperature \(\left(T_{k}\right)\).
What is peptization?
Peptization is the process of conversion of a precipitate into colloidal state in the presence of some electrolyte.
Why a negatively charged sol is obtained on adding \(\ce{AgNO3}\) solution to \(\ce{KI}\) solution?

When \(\ce{AgNO3}\) solution is added to aqueous KI solution, a negatively charged sol of \(\ce{AgI}\) is formed. This is due to selective adsorption of \(\ce{I-}\) ions from the dispersion medium. \[\begin{aligned} \ce{AgI}~~~~~~~~~+ ~~~~~& ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\ce{I-} ~~~~~~~~~~~~~\longrightarrow & \ce{[AgI]I-} \\ & \text{Dispersion medium} & \text{Negative sol} \end{aligned}\]
Out of \(\ce{KI}\) or \(\ce{K2SO4}\), which electrolyte is better in the coagulation of positive sol?
\(K_{2} SO_{4}\) is more effective in causing coagulation of positively charged colloidal sol. (because greater the valency of the coagulating ion, greater is its power to bring about coagulation)
What is zeta potential?
The difference of potential between fixed layer and diffused layer of a colloidal sol is known as electrokinetic potential or zeta potential.
What is electrokinetic potential?
The difference of potential between fixed layer and diffused layer of a colloidal sol is known as electrokinetic potential or zeta potential.
What is a hydrosol?
Colloidal solution of solid (dispersed phase) in water (dispersion medium).
What is an aerosol?
Colloidal solution of a liquid (dispersed phase) in a gas (dispersion medium).
What is foam/froth?
Colloidal solution of gas (dispersion medium) in water (dispersion medium).
Why is coagulation of lyophilic sol difficult as compared to lyophobic sol?

• in lyophobic sol, there is hardly and affinity between the particles of dispersion medium and dispersed phase, therefore, it is unstable and can be easily coagulated
  • in lyophilic sol, since there is strong affinity between the particles, coagulation is rather difficult
Why is Tyndall effect not observed in true solutions?
Tyndall effect is not observed in true solution as the diameter of dispersed particles is much smaller as compared to wavelength of the light used.
What is dialysis of colloidal solutions?

It is the process of removing a dissolved substance from a colloidal solution by means of diffusion through a suitable membrane.

  • a bag of suitable membrane containing the colloidal solution is suspended in a vessel through which fresh water is continuously flowing
  • the molecules and ions diffuse through membrane into the water and pure colloidal solution is left behind.
What happens when a colloidal solution undergoes persistent dialysis?

• when dialysis is persistent and prolonged, the traces of electrolyte present in sol are removed completely
  • these electrolytes stabilise the colloid and when removed completely, make the colloid unstable and the colloid gets coagulated
What happens when oppositely charged sols are mixed?
When equal proportions of oppositely charged sols are mixed, they neutralise each other resulting in coagulation.
A colloidal sol is prepared by the given method in figure. What is the charge on hydrated ferric oxide colloidal particles formed in the test tube? How is the sol represented?
What type of colloid is formed when a gas is dispersed in a liquid? Give an example.

When a gas is dispersed in a liquid, foam is formed.

  • e.g. froth
Out of \(\ce{BaCl_{2}}\) and \(\ce{KCl}\), which one is more effective in causing coagulation of a negatively charged colloidal sol? Give reason.

• \(\ce{BaCl_{2}}\) is more effective in causing coagulation of negatively charged colloidal sol
  • this is because greater the valency of the coagulating ion, greater is its power to bring about coagulation.
What are the dispersed phase and dispersion medium in milk?

Liquid fat : dispersed phase
Water : dispersion medium
Which aerosol depletes ozone layer?
CFC (Chlorofluorocarbon)
Which ion is formed when \(\ce{AgBr}\) is washed with hypo solution in photography?

• when the developed film is immersed in Sodium Thiosulphate (hypo) solution it removes unchanged Silver Bromide as a complex ion (Sodium Argentothisoluphate).
  • this is known as fixing
  • \[\ce{AgBr} + \ce{2 Na_{2}S_{2}O_{3}} \longrightarrow \ce{Na_{3}\left[Ag \left(S_{2}O_{3}\right)_{2}\right]}+ \ce{NaBr}\]
  • after fixing, the film is not sensitive to light anymore
How can a colloidal solution and true solution of the same colour be distinguished from each other?
When a powerful beam of light is passed through true and colloidal solutions each kept in a glass vessel then, colloidal solution exhibits Tyndall effect whereas the true solution does not
What happens when a freshly prepared precipitate of \(\ce{Fe(OH)_{3}}\) is shaken with a small amount of \(\ce{FeCl_{3}}\) solution?

• reddish brown coloured colloidal solution is formed
  • \(\ce{{Fe}^{3+}}\) ions from Ferric Chloride are adsorbed by \(\ce{Fe(OH)_{3}}\) precipitate
    \[\begin{aligned} & Fe ( OH )_{3} + ~~~~~~~~~Fe ^{3+} ~~~~~~~~~\longrightarrow~~~~~~~ Fe ( OH )_{3} . Fe ^{3+} \\ & ~~~~\text{(ppt)} ~~~~~~~~~~\text{(electrolyte)} ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~\text{(colloidal sol)} \end{aligned}\]
How can we prepare \(\ce{Fe(OH)_{3}}\) sol from \(\ce{FeCl_{3}}\)?

Ferric hydroxide forms a hydrophobic sol. Hence it is prepared indirectly by the hydrolysis of ferric chloride with boiling water. \[FeCl _{3}+3 H _{2} O \longrightarrow \underset{\text{Sol}}{Fe ( OH )_{3}}+3 HCl\]
Out of \(\ce{MgCl _{2}}\) and \(\ce{AlCl _{3}}\), which one is more effective in causing coagulation of negatively charged sol, and why?

• according to Hardy-Schulze rule, for negatively charged sol greater the valency of positive ion added to it, greater is its coagulation power
  • in \(\ce{AlCl_{3}}\), \(\ce{Al}\) has \(+3\) charge which is more than Mg with \(+2\) charge in \(\ce{MgCl_{2}}\)
  • thus, \(\ce{AlCl_{3}}\) is more effective in causing coagulation of negatively charged sol
Can proteins form multimolecular colloids?
Proteins are macromolecules which cannot form multimolecular colloids.
Can Sulphur sol form multimolecular colloids?
Sulphur sol has smaller \(S_{8}\) molecules, which can form multimolecular colloids.
Why does leather get hardened after tanning?

• animal hides are colloidal in nature
  • when a hide, which has positively charged particles is soaked in tannin, containing negatively charged colloidal particles, mutual coagulation takes place
  • this results in the hardening of leather
How is Sulphur sol prepared?

Sulphur sol is prepared by the oxidation of \(\ce{H_{2}S}\) with \(\ce{SO_{2}}\) \[ \ce{SO_{2}}+ \ce{2H_{2}S} ~~~~
\xrightarrow{\text{Oxidation}} ~~~\underset{\text { (Sol) }}{\ce{3 S }}+\ce{2 H _{2} O}\]
How is Gold sol prepared?

Gold sol is prepared by the reduction of \(\ce{AuCl_{3}}\) with \(\ce{HCHO}\). \[\begin{aligned} \ce{2AuCl_{3}}+ \underset{\text{(Formalin solution)}}{\ce{3HCHO} + \ce{3H_{2}O}} ~~\xrightarrow{\text{ Reduction }}~~ \underset{\text{ (Sol) }}{\ce{2Au}} + \ce{3HCOOH}+ \ce{6HCl} \end{aligned} \]
Explain the cleansing action of soap.

• the cleansing action of soap is due to the fact that soap molecules form micelle around the oil droplet in such a way that hydrophobic part is in the oil droplet and hydrophilic part interact with water
  • the oil droplet surrounded by stearate ions is now pulled in water and removed from the dirty surface
  • the negatively charged sheath around the globules prevents them from coming together and forming aggregates
  • thus, soap helps in emulsification and washing away of oils and fats
Why do soaps not work in hard water?

• hard water contains Calcium and Magnesium ions.
  • these ions form insoluble Calcium and Magnesium salts when Sodium or Potassium soaps are dissolved in hard water
  • these insoluble soaps separate as scum in water and are useless as cleansing agent
How does addition of alum purify water?

• the water obtained from natural sources often contains suspended impurities
  • Alum is added to such water to coagulate the suspended impurities and make water fit for drinking purposes
What happens when \(\ce{NaCl}\) solution is added to hydrated ferric oxide sol?

• \(\ce{NaCl}\) dissociates to give \(\ce{Na+}\) and \(\ce{Cl-}\) ions.
  • particles of Ferric Hydroxide sol are positively charged
  • hence, Ferric Hydroxide colloidal particles get coagulated by the oppositely charged \(\ce{Cl^{-}}\) ions
Why are medicines more effective in colloidal state?
Medicines are more effective in colloidal form because in this form, these are more easily assimilated due to large surface area.
"A delta is formed at the meeting point of sea water and river water". Explain why?

• sea water contains a lot of electrolytes
  • river contains colloids of sand and clay
  • when they meet, the electrolytes neutralise the charge on colloidal particles which results in the precipitation of sand, clay etc. This results in a delta formation
"Artificial rain is caused by spraying salt over clouds". Explain why?

• clouds are colloidal dispersion of water particles in air
    • these water particles carry some charge over them
  • on spraying oppositely charged colloidal dust or sand particles over a cloud from an airplane, the colloidal water particles present in the cloud will get neutralized
    • as a result they come closer and grow in size to form bigger water drops
  • ultimately, they will coagulate or precipitate causing artificial rain
Dispersed phase of smoke is {{c1::solid}}.
Dispersion medium of smoke is {{c1::gas}}.
Dispersed phase of milk is {{c1::fat (liquid)}}.
Dispersion medium of milk is {{c1::water (liquid)}}.
Animal hides are {{c1::colloidal}} in nature.
Hardening of leather in tanning industry is based on {{c1::mutual coagulation}}.
The size of colloidal particles is {{c1::between \(10^{-9}\) to \(10^{-6}\space m\) (diameter)}}.

Give an example of a promoter.
\(\ce{Mo}\) acts as a promoter in Haber's process.
List all group-15 elements.

\(\ce{N}\) \(\ce{P}\) \(\ce{As}\) \(\ce{Sb}\) \(\ce{Bi}\) \(\ce{Mc}\)
Nitrogen Phosphorous Arsenic Antimony Bismuth Moscovium
Trend of metallic characters in group 15.

• \(\ce{N}\), \(\ce{P}\) : non-metals
  • \(\ce{As}\), \(\ce{Sb}\) : metalloids
  • \(\ce{Bi}\) : metal
Trend of atomic radii in group 15.

\[\ce{N} \quad \ce{P} \quad \ce{As} \quad \ce{Sb} \quad \ce{Bi} \quad \ce{Mc}\]

  • increase down the group
  • smaller than group 14 elements (due to increased nuclear charge)
Why are group 15 elements smaller than group 14 elements?
Due to increased nuclear charge of group 15, group 15 elements are smaller.
Trend of melting points in group 15.
• increase from \(\ce{N}\) to \(\ce{As}\) and then decrease
Trend of boiling points in group 15.
• increase from \(\ce{N}\) to \(\ce{Sb}\) and then decrease very slightly
Trend of ionisation enthalpy in group 15.
• decreases regularly down the group (due to increase in size)
Trend of electronegativity in group 15.

\[\ce{N} \quad \ce{P} \quad \ce{As} \quad \ce{Sb} \quad \ce{Bi} \quad \ce{Mc}\]

  • decreases down the group
List all the allotropes of group 15 elements.

• Nitrogen ( \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) -Nitrogen)
  • Phosphorus (white, red, scarlet, violet, \(\alpha\) - black, \(\beta\) -black)
  • Arsenic (grey, yellow, black)
  • Antimony (metallic, yellow, explosive)
Trend of stability of oxidation state(s) in group 15.

• stability of \(+3\) oxidation state increases down the group
  • stability of \(+5\) oxidation state decreases down the group
    (these are due to due to inert pair effect)
Formation of halides in group 15 elements.

• \(\ce{MX3}\) : formed by all elements
  • \(\ce{MX5}\) : formed by all elements except Nitrogen

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NCl3}\), \(\ce{NF3}\), \(\ce{NBr3}\) (stability)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{SbCl3}\), \(\ce{PCl3}\), \(\ce{AsCl3}\) (Lewis acid strength)
\(\ce{SbCl3}\) < \(\ce{AsCl3}\) < \(\ce{PCl3}\)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{PI3}\), \(\ce{PF3}\), \(\ce{PBr3}\) (Lewis acid strength)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NI3}\), \(\ce{NCl3}\), \(\ce{PBr3}\), \(\ce{NF3}\) (Lewis base strength)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{PI3}\), \(\ce{PCl3}\), \(\ce{PBr3}\), \(\ce{PF3}\) (bond angle)

\(\ce{PF3}\) < \(\ce{PCl3}\) < \(\ce{PBr3}\) < \(\ce{PI3}\)
(this is due to increasing b.p.=b.p. repulsions)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\) (ease of formation)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\) (stability)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\) (basic character)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\) (solubility)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\) (bond angle)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\) (strength of \(\ce{M-H}\) bond)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\) (dipole moment)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\) (decomposition temperature)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\) (reducing character)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\) (covalent character)

\(\ce{BiH3}\) < \(\ce{SbH3}\) < \(\ce{AsH3}\) < \(\ce{PH3}\) < \(\ce{NH3}\)

  • As we move down the group, radius of elements increases and electronegativity decreases
  • So, ionic character of compounds increases and covalent nature decreases.

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\) (poisonous nature)

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\) (rate of combustion)
Which are the oxides formed by group 15 elements?

\[\ce{N} \quad \ce{P} \quad \ce{As} \quad \ce{Sb} \quad \ce{Bi} \quad \ce{Mc}\]

  • all these elements form oxides of the type \(\ce{X2O3}\), \(\ce{X2O4}\), and \(\ce{X2O5}\)
How to predict the order of acidic nature of group 15 oxides?
General electronic configuration of group 15 elements is {{c1::\(n s^{2} n p^{3}\)}}.
Physical state of \(\ce{N2}\) is {{c1::gas}}.
Physical state of \(\ce{P4}\) is {{c1::solid}}.
Physical state of \(\ce{As4}\) is {{c1::solid}}.
Physical state of \(\ce{Sb4}\) is {{c1::solid}}.
Physical state of \(\ce{Bi}\) is {{c1::solid}}.
Stability of \(+3\) oxidation state {{c1::increases}} down group 15.
Stability of \(+5\) oxidation state {{c1::decreases}} down group 15.
Why is the single \(\ce{N - N}\) bond weaker than the single \(\ce{P - P}\) bond?

• the single \(\ce{N - N}\) bond is weaker than the single \(\ce{P - P}\) bond
  • this is because of high interelectronic repulsion of the non-bonding electrons, occurring due to the small bond length
"Nitrogen does not form pentahalide." Explain Why?
Nitrogen cannot expand its octet due to absence of \(d\) -orbitals.

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NH_{3} }\), \(\ce{PH _{3} }\), \(\ce{AsH _{3} }\), \(\ce{SbH _{3} }\), \(\ce{BiH _{3} }\) (base strength)
"Increasing Lewis base strength order is \(\ce{BiH _{3}< SbH _{3}< AsH _{3}< PH _{3}< NH _{3} }\)." Explain why?

• the reason for this order is that as we move from \(\ce{BiH_{3} }\) to \(\ce{NH_{3} }\) the size of the central atom decreases
  • hence, lone pair is easily available for donation in the smaller atoms
  • the electron density on the central atom increases on moving from \(\ce{BiH_{3} }\) to \(\ce{NH_{3} }\), and so the basic strength also increases.
"\(\ce{BiH _{3} }\) is the strongest reducing agent amongst all the hydrides of group 15." Explain why?

• among hydrides of group-15 elements, the bond length increases from \(\ce{N - H}\) to \(\ce{Bi-H}\) with increasing size of element
  • \(\ce{Bi-H}\) bond is longest and weakest, it can break more easily and evolve \(\ce{H_{2} }\) gas which acts as the reducing agent.
Why does \(R_{3}P=O\) exist but \(R_{3}N=O\) does not? \((R=\) alkyl group)

• \(R_{3} N = O\) molecule has five covalent bonds with \(\ce{N}\) atom. The octet in \(\ce{N}\) cannot be extended as it does not have \(d\) -orbitals for the formation of \(p \pi-d \pi\) bond
  • in the case of \(R_{3} P = O\), \(\ce{P}\) can extend its octet since it has empty d-orbitals in its valence shell and form \(p \pi-d \pi\) bond
Why is \(\ce{NH _{3} }\) more basic than \(\ce{PH _{3} }\)?

• Lewis basic nature of \(\ce{NH _{3} }\) and \(\ce{PH _{3} }\) molecules is due to the presence of lone pairs on \(\ce{N}\) and \(\ce{P}\) atoms, respectively
  • \(\ce{P}\) atom is much larger than \(\ce{N}\) atom and also has empty \(d\) -orbitals
  • electron density due to lone pair on P gets diffused because of the presence of d-orbitals and so the lone pair is not easily available for donation.
  • hence, \(\ce{NH _{3} }\) is more basic than \(\ce{PH _{3} }\)
Explain why : "\(\ce{Bi}\) is a strong oxidizing agent in the \(+5\) state"

• Due to the largest atomic volume of \(\ce{Bi}\) and it having the largest nuclear charge, \(+5\) oxidation state of \(\ce{Bi}\) is less stable and has a strong tendency to accept electrons and reduce to stable \(+3\) state.
  • Therefore, \(\ce{Bi}\) in \(+5\) oxidation state acts as a strong oxidising agent.
Explain why : "\(\ce{PCl5}\) is known but \(\ce{NCl5}\) is not known."
Nitrogen cannot expand its valency beyond 4 due to absence of \(d\) -orbitals, whereas phosphorus shows pentavalency due to presence of \(d\) -orbitals.
{{c1::\(\ce{BiH _{3} }\)}} is the strongest reducing agent amongst all the hydrides of group 15.

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\), \(\ce{AsH3}\), \(\ce{BiH3}\), \(\ce{SbH3}\) (boiling points)

\(\ce{PH3< AsH3< NH3<SbH3<BiH3}\)

  • the abnormally high boiling point of \(\ce{NH3}\) is due to the intramolecular H-bonding
  • further as we move from \(\ce{PH_{3} }\) to \(\ce{BiH_{3} }\) the molecular mass increases
  • as a result, the Van der Waals forces of attraction increase and the boiling points increase regularly from \(\ce{PH_{3} }\) to \(\ce{BiH_{3} }\)
Explain why : "\(\ce{NF_{3} }\) is an exothermic compound whereas \(\ce{NCl_{3} }\) is not"

• in case of nitrogen, only \(\ce{NF_{3} }\) is known to be stable. \(N-F\) bond strength is greater than \(F-F\) bond strength; therefore formation of \(\ce{NF_{3} }\) is spontaneous
  • in case of \(\ce{NCl_{3} }\), \(N - Cl\) bond strength is lesser than Cl-Cl bond strength. Thus, energy has to be supplied during the formation of \(\ce{NCl_{3} }\)
Why is nitrogen gas very unreactive?
The bond dissociation enthalpy of triple bond in \(N \equiv N\) is very high due to \(p \pi-p \pi\) overlap. Hence, \(\ce{N_{2} }\) is less reactive at room temperature.
Explain why : "\(\ce{PH_{3} }\) has lower boiling point than \(\ce{NH_{3} }\)"
Unlike \(\ce{NH3}\), \(\ce{PH3}\) molecules are not associated through hydrogen bonding in liquid state. Therefore, the boiling point of \(\ce{PH_{3} }\) is lower than \(\ce{NH_{3} }\)
Explain why : "\(\ce{BiCl3}\) is more stable than \(\ce{BiCl5}\)"
\(\ce{BiCl3}\) is more stable than \(\ce{BiCl5}\), because on moving down the group, the stability of \(+5\) oxidation state decreases while \(+3\) oxidation state increases due to inert pair effect.
Explain why : "Nitrogen is found in gaseous state"

• Nitrogen exists as a diatomic molecule with a triple bond between two atoms.
  • These \(\ce{N2}\) molecules are held together by weak van der Waals force of attraction which can be easily broken by the collision of the molecules at room temperature.
  • Therefore, \(\ce{N2}\) is a gas at room temperature.
Explain why : "Phosphorus has greater tendency for catenation than Nitrogen"

• The property of catenation depends upon the strength of the element-element bond.
  • Since \(P - P \space\left(213 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\right)\) bond strength is much more than \(N - N \space \left(159 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\right)\) bond strength, Phosphorus shows more catenation properties than Nitrogen.
Explain why : "Tendency to form pentahalides decreases down the group in group 15 of the periodic table"
Due to inert pair effect the stability of \(+5\) oxidation state decreases down the group in group 15 . Hence, tendency to form pentahalide decreases down the group 15 of the periodic table.
Draw the structure of \(\ce{NF_{3} }\)

• total no. of electrons around the central \(N\) atom \(=5\)
  • No. of bond pairs \(=3\)
    No. of lone pairs \(=1\)
    Hybridisation \(=s p^{3}\)
  • therefore, according to VSEPR theory, \(\ce{NF_{3} }\) should be pyramidal.
Explain why : "\(+3\) oxidation state becomes more and more stable from \(\ce{As}\) to \(\ce{Bi}\) in the group"
On moving down the group, the stability of \(+5\) oxidation state decreases while that of \(+3\) oxidation state increases due to inert pair effect.
Explain why : "\(\ce{BiCl3}\) is less covalent than \(\ce{PCl3}\)"

• \(\ce{P^{3+}}\) is smaller in size as compared to \(\ce{Bi^{3+}}\).
  • According to Fajan's rule, smaller the cation, higher will be the covalent nature of the bond.
  • Hence, \(\ce{BiCl3}\) is less covalent than \(\ce{PCl3}\).
Among the hydrides of group-15 elements, which has the lowest boiling point?
\(\ce{PH_{3} }\) (Phosphine)
Among the hydrides of group-15 elements, which has the maximum basic character?
\(\ce{NH_{3} }\) (Ammonia)
Among the hydrides of group-15 elements, which has the highest bond angle?
\(\ce{NH_{3} }\) (Ammonia)
Among the hydrides of group-15 elements, which has the maximum reducing character?
\(\ce{BiH_{3} }\) (Bismuth Hydride)
What happens when \(\ce{(NH4)2Cr2O7}\) is heated?

When orange red crystals of Ammonium Dichromate are heated, these crystals decompose violently evolving nitrogen and green coloured Chromic Oxide is formed. \[\underset{\text{(Orange red)} }{\ce{(NH4)2Cr2O7} } \stackrel{\Delta}{\longrightarrow} \underset{\text{(Green)} }{\ce{Cr2O3} } + \ce{N2} +\ce{4H2O}\]
Explain why : "\(\ce{N2}\) is less reactive at room temperature"

In \(\ce{N2}\) molecule, \(\ce{N}\) atoms are held by triple bonds. It has very high bond dissociation energy \(\left(941.4 \space kJ \space mol^{-1}\right)\). Therefore \(N _{2}\) is inert at room temperature.
Write the formula of the compound of Phosphorus which is obtained when \(\text{conc. } \ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{P4}\).
\(\ce{H3PO4}\) (Phosphoric acid) is obtained when conc. \(\ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{P4}\). \[\ce{P4}+ 20 \ce{HNO3}_\text{(conc.)} \longrightarrow \ce{4H3PO4} + \ce{20NO2}+4 \ce{H2O}\]
Write the formula of the compound of Sulphur which is obtained when conc.\(\ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{S8}\).
When conc. \(\ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{S8}\), it forms Sulphuric acid. \[\ce{S8}+\ce{48HNO3}_{\text{(conc.)} } \longrightarrow \ce{8H2SO4} + \ce{48NO2}+ \ce{16H2O}\]
Write the formula of the compound of Iodine which is obtained when conc.\(\ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{I2}\).
Iodic acid \(\ce{(HIO3)}\) is formed when conc. \(\ce{HNO3}\) oxidises \(\ce{I2}\). \[I _{2}+10 HNO _{3(\text {conc.})} \longrightarrow 2 HIO _{3}+10 NO _{2}+4 H _{2} O\]

"When dilute Ferrous Sulphate solution is added to an aqueous solution containing Nitrate ion followed by careful addition of concentrated Sulphuric acid along the sides of test tube, a brown ring is formed at the interface between the solution and Sulphuric acid layers"
Which anion is confirmed by the appearance of brown ring and what is it's composition?
The brown ring at the interface between the solution and Sulphuric acid layers indicates the presence of Nitrate ion (\(\ce{NO_{3}^{-} }\)) in solution.
Explain why : "Sulphur is a polyatomic solid whereas oxygen is a diatomic gas"

• \(\ce{O2}\) molecules are held together by weak van der Waals' forces because of the small size and high electronegativity of oxygen.
  • Sulphur shows catenation and the molecule is made up of eight atoms \(\left(\ce{S8}\right)\) with strong intermolecular attractive forces. Hence, Sulphur exists as solid at room temperature.
Explain why : "Tendency to show \(-2\) oxidation state decreases from Oxygen to Tellurium"
Tendency to show \(-2\) oxidation decreases from Oxygen to Tellurium because electronegativity decreases on moving down the group.
Explain why : "\(\ce{SO2}\) is a reducing agent, whilst \(\ce{TeO2}\) is an oxidising agent"

• \(\ce{S + O2 \rightarrow SO2}\)
    • Oxidation number of Sulphur changes from \(0\) to \(+4\).
    • Due to presence of \(d\)-orbitals (vacant) Sulphur can extend its covalency and oxidation states till \(+6\), which is stable in Sulphur (eg: \(\ce{SF6}\)).
  • \(\ce{Te + O2 \rightarrow TeO2}\)
    • Oxidation number of Tellurium changes from \(0\) to \(+4\).
    • Unlike Sulphur, Tellurium cannot show \(+6\) oxidation state as it is highly unstable due to inert pair effect.
    • Therefore, \(\ce{Te}\) can only show a decrease in its oxidation state (it can decrease to \(-2,+2\)). Hence, it acts as an oxidising agent.

Arrange in increasing order :
\(\ce{H2O}\), \(\ce{H2Se}\), \(\ce{H2S}\), \(\ce{H2Te}\) (acidic character )

\(\ce{H2O}\)<\(\ce{H2S}\)<\(\ce{H2Se}\)<\(\ce{H2Te}\)

  • as the atomic size increases down the group, the bond length increases, hence, the bond strength decreases
  • consequently, the cleavage of \(M- H\) bond (where \(M= \ce{O , S , Se , Te,}\) etc.) becomes easier.
  • as a result, the tendency to release hydrogen as proton increases, that is, acidic strength increases down the group.
\(\ce{P4}+ \ce{HNO3}_\text {(conc.)}\) \(\longrightarrow\) {{c1::\(\ce{H3PO4} + \ce{NO2}+\ce{H2O}\)}}
\(\ce{S8}+\ce{HNO3}_{\text{(conc.)} }\) \(\longrightarrow\) {{c1::\(\ce{H2SO4} + \ce{NO2}+ \ce{H2O}\)}}
\(\ce{I2 + HNO3_{\text{(dilute)} } }\) \(\longrightarrow\) {{c1::\(\ce{HIO3} + \ce{NO2}+ \ce{H2O}\)}}
\(\ce{Cu + HNO3_{\text{(dilute)} } }\) \(\longrightarrow\) {{c1::\(\ce{Cu(NO3)2} + \ce{NO}+ \ce{H2O}\)}}
Explain why : "\(\ce{NH3}\) has an abnormally high boiling point"

• in group-15, the order of increasing boiling points of hydrides goes as follows : \(\ce{PH3< AsH3< NH3<SbH3<BiH3}\)
  • the abnormally high boiling point of \(\ce{NH3}\) is due to the intramolecular H-bonding it exhibits
Explain why : "Net dipole moment of \(\ce{NH3}\) is higher than that of \(\ce{NF3}\)"

• In \(\ce{NH_{3} }\) the bond moment and lone pair moment work in same direction. Hence, net dipole moment is higher.
  • In \(\ce{NF_{3} }\) the bond moment and lone pair moment work in opposite direction. Hence, net dipole moment is lower.
Net dipole moment of \(\ce{NH3}\) is {{c1::higher}} than that of \(\ce{NF3}\).
Electronegativity of Nitrogen is {{c1::greater}} than that of Hydrogen.
Electronegativity of Nitrogen is {{c1::lesser}} than that of Fluorine.
Explain why : "The molecules \(\ce{NH_{3} }\) and \(\ce{NF_{3} }\) have dipole moments which are of opposite direction"

• in \(\ce{NH3}\), Nitrogen is more electronegative than Hydrogen
  • whereas in \(\ce{NF3}\), Nitrogen is less electronegative than Fluorine.

    โฆ which explains the opposite directions of respective dipole moments.

Arrange in increasing order :
Hydrides of group 16 (reducing character)

\[\ce{H _{2} S < H _{2} Se < H _{2} Te}\]

  • Hydrides of all elements of group 16 except that of Oxygen, are reducing agents.
  • The reducing character, increases from \(\ce{H2S}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\) because of increasing size of atoms from \(\ce{S}\) to \(\ce{Te}\) which results in weaker \(M-H\) bond.
Explain why : "\(\ce{SF6}\) is inert towards hydrolysis"

In \(\ce{SF6}\), \(\ce{S}\) atom is sterically protected by six \(F\) atoms and does not allow any reagent to attack on the \(\ce{S}\) atom. Due to this, \(\ce{SF6}\) is kinetically an inert substance.
Can \(\ce{SF6}\) undergo hydrolysis?
No, \(\ce{SF6}\) is inert towards hydrolysis.
Explain why : "Thermal stability decreases from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\)"
As the size of central atom increases, \(M - H\) bond becomes weaker and longer and hence, thermal stability decreases while going from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\).
Explain why : "There is a large difference between the melting and boiling points of Oxygen and Sulphur"

• Oxygen molecules are held together by weak Van der Waals' forces because of the small size and high electronegativity of Oxygen.
  • Sulphur shows catenation and the molecule is made up of 8 atoms with strong intermolecular forces - hence there is large difference in the melting and boiling points of Oxygen and Sulphur.
Explain why : "\(\ce{H2Te}\) is the strongest reducing agent amongst all the hydrides of group 16 elements"

• Bond dissociation enthalpy, and hence thermal stability of hydrides decreases from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\).
  • Therefore, \(\ce{H2Te}\) releases hydrogen readily - which makes \(\ce{H2Te}\) the strongest reducing agent amongst all the hydrides of group 16.
Explain why : "Elements of group 16 generally show lower value of first ionization enthalpy compared to the corresponding elements of group 15"

• The first ionization enthalpy of group 16 elements is lower than those of group 15 elements despite their smaller atomic radii and higher nuclear charge
  • This is due to the relatively symmetrical and more stable configuration of the elements of group 15 as compared to those of the elements of group 16
Explain why : "The electron gain enthalpy of Oxygen is less negative than Sulphur"

• The electron gain enthalpy of Oxygen is less negative than Sulphur - this is due to its small size, as a result of which the electron-electron repulsion in the relatively small \(2 p\) subshell are comparatively larger
  • Hence, the incoming electrons are not accepted with same ease as in case of other (Sulphur) elements of this group.

Arrange in increasing order:
\(\ce{O , S , Te , Se}\) (increasing order of electron gain enthalpy with negative sign)

\[ \begin{array}{llllll} &\ce{~~~~O}~~~ < &\ce{~~~~Po}~~~ < &\ce{~~~~Te}~~~ < &\ce{~~~~Se}~~~ < &\ce{~~~~S}~~~ \\ \Delta_{e g} H\left( kJ mol ^{-1}\right) & -141 & -174 & -190 & -195 & -200 \\ \text{(-ve sign shows release of energy)} \end{array} \]

  • Electron gain enthalpy of oxygen is less negative than Sulphur due to compact size of oxygen atom (inter-electronic repulsion is more in \(O\) )
  • From Sulphur onwards, enthalpy again becomes less negative up to \(\ce{Po}\).
Explain why : "\(\ce{H2S}\) is more acidic than \(\ce{H2O}\)"

• As the atomic size increases down the group, the bond length increases and hence, the bond strength decreases.
  • Consequently, the cleavage of \(M-H\) bond (\(M= \ce{ O , S , Se , Te,}\) etc.) becomes easier - as result, the tendency to release hydrogen as proton increases i.e., acidic strength increases down the group.
  • hence, \(\ce{H2S}\) is more acidic than \(\ce{H2O}\)
Explain why : "Sulphur has a greater tendency for catenation than oxygen"

• The property of catenation depends upon \(E-E\) bond strength of the element.
  • As \(S - S\) bond is much stronger \(\left(213 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\right)\) than \(O - O\) bond \(\left(138 \space kJ \space mol ^{-1}\right)\), Sulphur has greater tendency for catenation than oxygen.
Explain why : "\(\ce{H2S}\) is less acidic than \(\ce{H2Te}\)"

• As the atomic size increases down the group, the bond length increases and hence, the bond strength decreases.
  • Consequently, the cleavage of \(M-H\) bond \((M= O , S , Se , Te\), etc.) becomes easier - as result, the tendency to release hydrogen as proton increases i.e., acidic strength increases down the group.
  • hence, \(\ce{H2S}\) is less acidic than \(\ce{H2Te}\)
Explain why : "Boiling point of water is much higher than that of hydrogen sulphide"

• The abnormally high boiling point of \(\ce{H2O}\) is due to strong intermolecular H-bonding.
  • Since, all other elements have much lower electronegativity than oxygen, they do not undergo similar H-bonding.
Explain why : "Thermal stability of water is much higher than that of \(\ce{H2S}\)"
As the size of central atom increases, \(M - H\) bond becomes weaker and longer and hence, thermal stability decreases while going from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\).
Thermal stability {{c1::decreases}} from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\) (increases/decreases?)
{{c1::\(\ce{H2Te}\)}} is the strongest {{c2::reducing}} agent amongst all the hydrides of group 16 elements.
Elements of group 16 generally show {{c1::lower}} value of first ionization enthalpy compared to the corresponding elements of group 15. (higher/lower?)
The electron gain enthalpy of Oxygen is {{c1::less}} negative than Sulphur. (more/less?)

  • \(\ce{Se}\), \(\ce{Te}\) : metalloids
  • \(\ce{Po}\) : radioactive

Trend of boiling points in group 16.

Do group 16 elements show allotropy?
Yes, all elements in group 16 show allotropy.
Among the hydrides of group 16, which has the maximum bond angle?

\[\ce{H2O}\]

  • All the group 16 hydrides have angular shape involving \(s p^{3}\) hybridisation due to stronger lone pair-lone pair repulsions than bond pair-bond pair repulsions, the bond angle in water decreases from the tetrahedral value.
  • As we move down the group from \(O\) to \(Te\), the size of central atom increases and its electronegativity decreases.
  • As a result, the position of the two bond pairs shifts away from the central atom as we move from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\). Consequently the repulsions between the bond pairs decreases from \(\ce{H2O}\) to \(\ce{H2Te}\) and therefore bond angle decreases.
  • That's the reason why \(\ce{H2O}\) has the highest bond angle among group 16 hydrides.
Among the hydrides of group 16, which is the most thermally stable?

\[\ce{H2O}\]

  • As the size of the element increases down the group, the \(E - H\) bond dissociation energy decreases and hence \(E - H\) bond breaks more easily.
  • Thus, \(\ce{H2O}\) has the highest thermal stability among group 16 hydrides.
Explain why : "Moist \(\ce{SO2}\) gas acts as a reducing agent."
In presence of moisture, \(\ce{SO2}\) acts as a reducing agent due to the evolution of nascent hydrogen.

Sulphur dioxide turns acidified Potassium Dichromate solution from orange to green.
